<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEBIANNAME[¶][2287]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When the [`debian`][2288] class is inherited, which is the default behavior, `DEBIANNAME` allows you to override the library name for an individual package. Overriding the library name in these cases is rare. You must use the package name as an override when you set this variable. Here is an example from the `dbus` recipe:

```
     DEBIANNAME_${PN} = "dbus-1"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEBUG_BUILD[¶][2289]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies to build packages with debugging information. This influences the value of the`[SELECTED_OPTIMIZATION][1488]` variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEBUG_OPTIMIZATION[¶][2290]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The options to pass in `[TARGET_CFLAGS][1489]` and `[CFLAGS][1490]` when compiling a system for debugging. This variable defaults to "-O -fno-omit-frame-pointer ${DEBUG_FLAGS} -pipe".

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEFAULT_PREFERENCE[¶][2291]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a weak bias for recipe selection priority.

The most common usage of this is variable is to set it to "-1" within a recipe for a development version of a piece of software. Using the variable in this way causes the stable version of the recipe to build by default in the absence of `[PREFERRED_VERSION][1491]` being used to build the development version.

### Note

The bias provided by `DEFAULT_PREFERENCE` is weak and is overridden by`[BBFILE_PRIORITY][1492]` if that variable is different between two layers that contain different versions of the same recipe.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEFAULTTUNE[¶][2292]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The default CPU and Application Binary Interface (ABI) tunings (i.e. the "tune") used by the OpenEmbedded build system. The `DEFAULTTUNE` helps define [`TUNE_FEATURES`][2293].

The default tune is either implicitly or explicitly set by the machine ([`MACHINE`][2294]). However, you can override the setting using available tunes as defined with [`AVAILTUNES`][2295].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEPENDS[¶][2296]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Lists a recipe's build-time dependencies. These are dependencies on other recipes whose contents (e.g. headers and shared libraries) are needed by the recipe at build time.

As an example, consider a recipe `foo` that contains the following assignment:

```
     DEPENDS = "bar"

```

The practical effect of the previous assignment is that all files installed by bar will be available in the appropriate staging sysroot, given by the [`STAGING_DIR*`][2297] variables, by the time the [`do_configure`][2298]task for `foo` runs. This mechanism is implemented by having `do_configure` depend on the[`do_populate_sysroot`][2299] task of each recipe listed in `DEPENDS`, through a `[`[`deptask`][2300]`]` declaration in the[`base`][2301] class.

### Note

It seldom is necessary to reference, for example, `STAGING_DIR_HOST` explicitly. The standard classes and build-related variables are configured to automatically use the appropriate staging sysroots.

As another example, `DEPENDS` can also be used to add utilities that run on the build machine during the build. For example, a recipe that makes use of a code generator built by the recipe `codegen`might have the following:

```
     DEPENDS = "codegen-native"

```

For more information, see the [`native`][2302] class and the [`EXTRANATIVEPATH`][2303] variable.

### Notes

*   `DEPENDS` is a list of recipe names. Or, to be more precise, it is a list of[`PROVIDES`][2] names, which usually match recipe names. Putting a package name such as "foo-dev" in `DEPENDS` does not make sense. Use "foo" instead, as this will put files from all the packages that make up `foo`, which includes those from `foo-dev`, into the sysroot.

*   One recipe having another recipe in `DEPENDS` does not by itself add any runtime dependencies between the packages produced by the two recipes. However, as explained in the "[Automatically Added Runtime Dependencies][3]" section, runtime dependencies will often be added automatically, meaning`DEPENDS` alone is sufficient for most recipes.

*   Counterintuitively, `DEPENDS` is often necessary even for recipes that install precompiled components. For example, if `libfoo` is a precompiled library that links against `libbar`, then linking against `libfoo` requires both `libfoo` and `libbar` to be available in the sysroot. Without a `DEPENDS` from the recipe that installs `libfoo` to the recipe that installs `libbar`, other recipes might fail to link against `libfoo`.

For information on runtime dependencies, see the [`RDEPENDS`][2304] variable. You can also see the "[Tasks][2305]" and "[Dependencies][2306]" sections in the BitBake User Manual for additional information on tasks and dependencies.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEPLOY_DIR[¶][2307]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Points to the general area that the OpenEmbedded build system uses to place images, packages, SDKs and other output files that are ready to be used outside of the build system. By default, this directory resides within the [Build Directory][2308] as `${TMPDIR}/deploy`.

For more information on the structure of the Build Directory, see "[The Build Directory - `build/`][2309]" section. For more detail on the contents of the `deploy` directory, see the "[Images][2310]", "[Package Feeds][2311]", and "[Application Development SDK][2312]" sections.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEPLOY_DIR_DEB[¶][2313]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Points to the area that the OpenEmbedded build system uses to place Debian packages that are ready to be used outside of the build system. This variable applies only when [`PACKAGE_CLASSES`][2314]contains "package_deb".

The BitBake configuration file initially defines the `DEPLOY_DIR_DEB` variable as a sub-folder of[`DEPLOY_DIR`][2315]:

```
     DEPLOY_DIR_DEB = "${DEPLOY_DIR}/deb"

```

The [`package_deb`][2316] class uses the `DEPLOY_DIR_DEB` variable to make sure the [`do_package_write_deb`][2317]task writes Debian packages into the appropriate folder. For more information on how packaging works, see the "[Package Feeds][2318]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEPLOY_DIR_IMAGE[¶][2319]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Points to the area that the OpenEmbedded build system uses to place images and other associated output files that are ready to be deployed onto the target machine. The directory is machine-specific as it contains the `${MACHINE}` name. By default, this directory resides within the [Build Directory][2320] as `${DEPLOY_DIR}/images/${MACHINE}/`.

For more information on the structure of the Build Directory, see "[The Build Directory - `build/`][2321]" section. For more detail on the contents of the `deploy` directory, see the "[Images][2322]" and "[Application Development SDK][2323]" sections.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEPLOY_DIR_IPK[¶][2324]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Points to the area that the OpenEmbedded build system uses to place IPK packages that are ready to be used outside of the build system. This variable applies only when [`PACKAGE_CLASSES`][2325] contains "package_ipk".

The BitBake configuration file initially defines this variable as a sub-folder of [`DEPLOY_DIR`][2326]:

```
     DEPLOY_DIR_IPK = "${DEPLOY_DIR}/ipk"

```

The [`package_ipk`][2327] class uses the `DEPLOY_DIR_IPK` variable to make sure the [`do_package_write_ipk`][2328]task writes IPK packages into the appropriate folder. For more information on how packaging works, see the "[Package Feeds][2329]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEPLOY_DIR_RPM[¶][2330]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Points to the area that the OpenEmbedded build system uses to place RPM packages that are ready to be used outside of the build system. This variable applies only when [`PACKAGE_CLASSES`][2331] contains "package_rpm".

The BitBake configuration file initially defines this variable as a sub-folder of [`DEPLOY_DIR`][2332]:

```
     DEPLOY_DIR_RPM = "${DEPLOY_DIR}/rpm"

```

The [`package_rpm`][2333] class uses the `DEPLOY_DIR_RPM` variable to make sure the [`do_package_write_rpm`][2334]task writes RPM packages into the appropriate folder. For more information on how packaging works, see the "[Package Feeds][2335]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEPLOY_DIR_TAR[¶][2336]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Points to the area that the OpenEmbedded build system uses to place tarballs that are ready to be used outside of the build system. This variable applies only when [`PACKAGE_CLASSES`][2337] contains "package_tar".

The BitBake configuration file initially defines this variable as a sub-folder of [`DEPLOY_DIR`][2338]:

```
     DEPLOY_DIR_TAR = "${DEPLOY_DIR}/tar"

```

The [`package_tar`][2339] class uses the `DEPLOY_DIR_TAR` variable to make sure the [`do_package_write_tar`][2340]task writes TAR packages into the appropriate folder. For more information on how packaging works, see the "[Package Feeds][2341]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DEPLOYDIR[¶][2342]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`deploy`][2343] class, the `DEPLOYDIR` points to a temporary work area for deployed files that is set in the `deploy` class as follows:

```
     DEPLOYDIR = "${WORKDIR}/deploy-${PN}"

```

Recipes inheriting the `deploy` class should copy files to be deployed into `DEPLOYDIR`, and the class will take care of copying them into [`DEPLOY_DIR_IMAGE`][2345] afterwards.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DESCRIPTION[¶][2346]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The package description used by package managers. If not set, `DESCRIPTION` takes the value of the[`SUMMARY`][2347] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISK_SIGNATURE[¶][2348]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A 32-bit MBR disk signature used by `directdisk` images.

By default, the signature is set to an automatically generated random value that allows the OpenEmbedded build system to create a boot loader. You can override the signature in the image recipe by setting `DISK_SIGNATURE` to an 8-digit hex string. You might want to override`DISK_SIGNATURE` if you want the disk signature to remain constant between image builds.

When using Linux 3.8 or later, you can use `DISK_SIGNATURE` to specify the root by UUID to allow the kernel to locate the root device even if the device name changes due to differences in hardware configuration. By default, `ROOT_VM` is set as follows:

```
     ROOT_VM ?= "root=/dev/sda2"

```

However, you can change this to locate the root device using the disk signature instead:

```
     ROOT_VM = "root=PARTUUID=${DISK_SIGNATURE}-02"

```

As previously mentioned, it is possible to set the `DISK_SIGNATURE` variable in your `local.conf` file to a fixed value if you do not want `syslinux.cfg` changing for each build. You might find this useful when you want to upgrade the root filesystem on a device without having to recreate or modify the master boot record.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO[¶][2349]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The short name of the distribution. This variable corresponds to a distribution configuration file whose root name is the same as the variable's argument and whose filename extension is `.conf`. For example, the distribution configuration file for the Poky distribution is named `poky.conf` and resides in the `meta-poky/conf/distro` directory of the [Source Directory][2350].

Within that `poky.conf` file, the `DISTRO` variable is set as follows:

```
     DISTRO = "poky"

```

Distribution configuration files are located in a `conf/distro` directory within the [Metadata][2351] that contains the distribution configuration. The value for `DISTRO` must not contain spaces, and is typically all lower-case.

### Note

If the `DISTRO` variable is blank, a set of default configurations are used, which are specified within `meta/conf/distro/defaultsetup.conf` also in the Source Directory.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_CODENAME[¶][2352]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a codename for the distribution being built.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_EXTRA_RDEPENDS[¶][2353]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of distro-specific packages to add to all images. This variable takes affect through`packagegroup-base` so the variable only really applies to the more full-featured images that include `packagegroup-base`. You can use this variable to keep distro policy out of generic images. As with all other distro variables, you set this variable in the distro `.conf` file.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_EXTRA_RRECOMMENDS[¶][2354]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of distro-specific packages to add to all images if the packages exist. The packages might not exist or be empty (e.g. kernel modules). The list of packages are automatically installed but you can remove them.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_FEATURES[¶][2355]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The software support you want in your distribution for various features. You define your distribution features in the distribution configuration file.

In most cases, the presence or absence of a feature in `DISTRO_FEATURES` is translated to the appropriate option supplied to the configure script during the [`do_configure`][2356] task for recipes that optionally support the feature. For example, specifying "x11" in `DISTRO_FEATURES`, causes every piece of software built for the target that can optionally support X11 to have its X11 support enabled.

Two more examples are Bluetooth and NFS support. For a more complete list of features that ships with the Yocto Project and that you can provide with this variable, see the "[Distro Features][2357]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_FEATURES_BACKFILL[¶][2358]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Features to be added to `[DISTRO_FEATURES][1493]` if not also present in`[DISTRO_FEATURES_BACKFILL_CONSIDERED][1494]`.

This variable is set in the `meta/conf/bitbake.conf` file. It is not intended to be user-configurable. It is best to just reference the variable to see which distro features are being backfilled for all distro configurations. See the [Feature backfilling][2359] section for more information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_FEATURES_BACKFILL_CONSIDERED[¶][2360]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Features from `[DISTRO_FEATURES_BACKFILL][1495]` that should not be backfilled (i.e. added to`[DISTRO_FEATURES][1496]`) during the build. See the "[Feature Backfilling][2361]" section for more information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_FEATURES_DEFAULT[¶][2362]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A convenience variable that gives you the default list of distro features with the exception of any features specific to the C library (`libc`).

When creating a custom distribution, you might find it useful to be able to reuse the default[`DISTRO_FEATURES`][2363] options without the need to write out the full set. Here is an example that uses`DISTRO_FEATURES_DEFAULT` from a custom distro configuration file:

```
     DISTRO_FEATURES ?= "${DISTRO_FEATURES_DEFAULT} ${DISTRO_FEATURES_LIBC} myfeature"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_FEATURES_FILTER_NATIVE[¶][2364]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of features that if present in the target [`DISTRO_FEATURES`][2365] value should be included in`DISTRO_FEATURES` when building native recipes. This variable is used in addition to the features filtered using the [`DISTRO_FEATURES_NATIVE`][2366] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_FEATURES_FILTER_NATIVESDK[¶][2367]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of features that if present in the target [`DISTRO_FEATURES`][2368] value should be included in`DISTRO_FEATURES` when building nativesdk recipes. This variable is used in addition to the features filtered using the [`DISTRO_FEATURES_NATIVESDK`][2369] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_FEATURES_LIBC[¶][2370]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A convenience variable that specifies the list of distro features that are specific to the C library (`libc`). Typically, these features are prefixed with "libc-" and control which features are enabled at during the build within the C library itself.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_FEATURES_NATIVE[¶][2371]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of features that should be included in [`DISTRO_FEATURES`][2372] when building native recipes. This variable is used in addition to the features filtered using the [`DISTRO_FEATURES_FILTER_NATIVE`][2373]variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_FEATURES_NATIVESDK[¶][2374]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of features that should be included in [`DISTRO_FEATURES`][2375] when building nativesdk recipes. This variable is used in addition to the features filtered using the[`DISTRO_FEATURES_FILTER_NATIVESDK`][2376] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_NAME[¶][2377]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The long name of the distribution.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTRO_VERSION[¶][2378]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The version of the distribution.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DISTROOVERRIDES[¶][2379]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A colon-separated list of overrides specific to the current distribution. By default, this list includes the value of [`DISTRO`][2380].

You can extend `DISTROOVERRIDES` to add extra overrides that should apply to the distribution.

The underlying mechanism behind `DISTROOVERRIDES` is simply that it is included in the default value of [`OVERRIDES`][2381].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DL_DIR[¶][2382]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The central download directory used by the build process to store downloads. By default, `DL_DIR`gets files suitable for mirroring for everything except Git repositories. If you want tarballs of Git repositories, use the [`BB_GENERATE_MIRROR_TARBALLS`][2383] variable.

You can set this directory by defining the `DL_DIR` variable in the `conf/local.conf` file. This directory is self-maintaining and you should not have to touch it. By default, the directory is `downloads` in the[Build Directory][2384].

```
     #DL_DIR ?= "${TOPDIR}/downloads"

```

To specify a different download directory, simply remove the comment from the line and provide your directory.

During a first build, the system downloads many different source code tarballs from various upstream projects. Downloading can take a while, particularly if your network connection is slow. Tarballs are all stored in the directory defined by `DL_DIR` and the build system looks there first to find source tarballs.

### Note

When wiping and rebuilding, you can preserve this directory to speed up this part of subsequent builds.

You can safely share this directory between multiple builds on the same development machine. For additional information on how the build process gets source files when working behind a firewall or proxy server, see this specific question in the "[FAQ][2385]" chapter. You can also refer to the "[Working Behind a Network Proxy][2386]" Wiki page.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">DOC_COMPRESS[¶][2387]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`compress_doc`][2388] class, this variable sets the compression policy used when the OpenEmbedded build system compresses man pages and info pages. By default, the compression method used is gz (gzip). Other policies available are xz and bz2.

For information on policies and on how to use this variable, see the comments in the`meta/classes/compress_doc.bbclass` file.

</dd>

</dl>

### E

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EFI_PROVIDER[¶][2389]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When building bootable images (i.e. where `hddimg` or `vmdk` is in [`IMAGE_FSTYPES`][2390]), the `EFI_PROVIDER`variable specifies the EFI bootloader to use. The default is "grub-efi", but "systemd-boot" can be used instead.

See the [`systemd-boot`][2391] and [`image-live`][2392] classes for more information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">ENABLE_BINARY_LOCALE_GENERATION[¶][2393]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Variable that controls which locales for `glibc` are generated during the build (useful if the target device has 64Mbytes of RAM or less).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">ERR_REPORT_DIR[¶][2394]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When used with the [`report-error`][2395] class, specifies the path used for storing the debug files created by the [error reporting tool][2396], which allows you to submit build errors you encounter to a central database. By default, the value of this variable is `${`[`LOG_DIR`][2397]`}/error-report`.

You can set `ERR_REPORT_DIR` to the path you want the error reporting tool to store the debug files as follows in your `local.conf` file:

```
     ERR_REPORT_DIR = "path"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">ERROR_QA[¶][2398]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the quality assurance checks whose failures are reported as errors by the OpenEmbedded build system. You set this variable in your distribution configuration file. For a list of the checks you can control with this variable, see the "[`insane.bbclass`][2399]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXCLUDE_FROM_SHLIBS[¶][2400]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Triggers the OpenEmbedded build system's shared libraries resolver to exclude an entire package when scanning for shared libraries.

### Note

The shared libraries resolver's functionality results in part from the internal function`package_do_shlibs`, which is part of the [`do_package`][2401] task. You should be aware that the shared libraries resolver might implicitly define some dependencies between packages.

The `EXCLUDE_FROM_SHLIBS` variable is similar to the [`PRIVATE_LIBS`][2402] variable, which excludes a package's particular libraries only and not the whole package.

Use the `EXCLUDE_FROM_SHLIBS` variable by setting it to "1" for a particular package:

```
     EXCLUDE_FROM_SHLIBS = "1"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXCLUDE_FROM_WORLD[¶][2403]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Directs BitBake to exclude a recipe from world builds (i.e. `bitbake world`). During world builds, BitBake locates, parses and builds all recipes found in every layer exposed in the `bblayers.conf`configuration file.

To exclude a recipe from a world build using this variable, set the variable to "1" in the recipe.

### Note

Recipes added to `EXCLUDE_FROM_WORLD` may still be built during a world build in order to satisfy dependencies of other recipes. Adding a recipe to `EXCLUDE_FROM_WORLD` only ensures that the recipe is not explicitly added to the list of build targets in a world build.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTENDPE[¶][2404]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Used with file and pathnames to create a prefix for a recipe's version based on the recipe's [`PE`][2405] value. If `PE` is set and greater than zero for a recipe, `EXTENDPE` becomes that value (e.g if `PE` is equal to "1" then `EXTENDPE` becomes "1_"). If a recipe's `PE` is not set (the default) or is equal to zero, `EXTENDPE`becomes "".

See the [`STAMP`][2406] variable for an example.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTENDPKGV[¶][2407]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The full package version specification as it appears on the final packages produced by a recipe. The variable's value is normally used to fix a runtime dependency to the exact same version of another package in the same recipe:

```
     RDEPENDS_${PN}-additional-module = "${PN} (= ${EXTENDPKGV})"

```

The dependency relationships are intended to force the package manager to upgrade these types of packages in lock-step.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTERNAL_KERNEL_TOOLS[¶][2408]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When set, the `EXTERNAL_KERNEL_TOOLS` variable indicates that these tools are not in the source tree.

When kernel tools are available in the tree, they are preferred over any externally installed tools. Setting the `EXTERNAL_KERNEL_TOOLS` variable tells the OpenEmbedded build system to prefer the installed external tools. See the [`kernel-yocto`][2409] class in `meta/classes` to see how the variable is used.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTERNALSRC[¶][2410]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`externalsrc`][2411] class, this variable points to the source tree, which is outside of the OpenEmbedded build system. When set, this variable sets the [`S`][2412] variable, which is what the OpenEmbedded build system uses to locate unpacked recipe source code.

For more information on `externalsrc.bbclass`, see the "[`externalsrc.bbclass`][2413]" section. You can also find information on how to use this variable in the "[Building Software from an External Source][2414]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTERNALSRC_BUILD[¶][2415]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`externalsrc`][2416] class, this variable points to the directory in which the recipe's source code is built, which is outside of the OpenEmbedded build system. When set, this variable sets the [`B`][2417] variable, which is what the OpenEmbedded build system uses to locate the Build Directory.

For more information on `externalsrc.bbclass`, see the "[`externalsrc.bbclass`][2418]" section. You can also find information on how to use this variable in the "[Building Software from an External Source][2419]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTRA_AUTORECONF[¶][2420]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

For recipes inheriting the [`autotools`][2421] class, you can use `EXTRA_AUTORECONF` to specify extra options to pass to the `autoreconf` command that is executed during the [`do_configure`][2422] task.

The default value is "--exclude=autopoint".

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTRA_IMAGE_FEATURES[¶][2423]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of additional features to include in an image. When listing more than one feature, separate them with a space.

Typically, you configure this variable in your `local.conf` file, which is found in the [Build Directory][2424]. Although you can use this variable from within a recipe, best practices dictate that you do not.

### Note

To enable primary features from within the image recipe, use the [`IMAGE_FEATURES`][2425]variable.

Here are some examples of features you can add:

```
"dbg-pkgs" - Adds -dbg packages for all installed packages
             including symbol information for debugging and
             profiling.

"debug-tweaks" - Makes an image suitable for debugging.
                 For example, allows root logins without
                 passwords and enables post-installation
                 logging. See the 'allow-empty-password'
                 and 'post-install-logging' features in
                 the "Image Features" section for
                 more information.

"dev-pkgs" - Adds -dev packages for all installed packages.
             This is useful if you want to develop against
             the libraries in the image.

"read-only-rootfs" - Creates an image whose root
                     filesystem is read-only. See the
                     "Creating a Read-Only Root Filesystem"
                     section in the Yocto Project
                     Development Manual for more
                     information

"tools-debug" - Adds debugging tools such as gdb and
                strace.

"tools-sdk" - Adds development tools such as gcc, make,
              pkgconfig and so forth.

"tools-testapps" - Adds useful testing tools such as
                   ts_print, aplay, arecord and so
                   forth.

```

For a complete list of image features that ships with the Yocto Project, see the "[Image Features][2428]" section.

For an example that shows how to customize your image by using this variable, see the "[Customizing Images Using Custom `IMAGE_FEATURES` and `EXTRA_IMAGE_FEATURES`][2429]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTRA_IMAGECMD[¶][2430]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies additional options for the image creation command that has been specified in [`IMAGE_CMD`][2431]. When setting this variable, you should use an override for the associated type. Here is an example:

```
     EXTRA_IMAGECMD_ext3 ?= "-i 4096"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTRA_IMAGEDEPENDS[¶][2432]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of recipes to build that do not provide packages for installing into the root filesystem.

Sometimes a recipe is required to build the final image but is not needed in the root filesystem. You can use the `EXTRA_IMAGEDEPENDS` variable to list these recipes and thus specify the dependencies. A typical example is a required bootloader in a machine configuration.

### Note

To add packages to the root filesystem, see the various `*[RDEPENDS][1497]` and `*[RRECOMMENDS][1498]` variables.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTRANATIVEPATH[¶][2433]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of subdirectories of `${`[`STAGING_BINDIR_NATIVE`][2434]`}` added to the beginning of the environment variable `PATH`. As an example, the following prepends "${STAGING_BINDIR_NATIVE}/foo:${STAGING_BINDIR_NATIVE}/bar:" to `PATH`:

```
     EXTRANATIVEPATH = "foo bar"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTRA_OECMAKE[¶][2435]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Additional `cmake` options.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTRA_OECONF[¶][2436]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Additional `configure` script options. See [`PACKAGECONFIG_CONFARGS`][2437] for additional information on passing configure script options.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTRA_OEMAKE[¶][2438]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Additional GNU `make` options.

Because the `EXTRA_OEMAKE` defaults to "", you need to set the variable to specify any required GNU options.

[`PARALLEL_MAKE`][2439] and [`PARALLEL_MAKEINST`][2440] also make use of `EXTRA_OEMAKE` to pass the required flags.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTRA_OESCONS[¶][2441]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`scons`][2442] class, this variable specifies additional configuration options you want to pass to the `scons` command line.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">EXTRA_USERS_PARAMS[¶][2443]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`extrausers`][2444] class, this variable provides image level user and group operations. This is a more global method of providing user and group configuration as compared to using the[`useradd`][2445] class, which ties user and group configurations to a specific recipe.

The set list of commands you can configure using the `EXTRA_USERS_PARAMS` is shown in the`extrausers` class. These commands map to the normal Unix commands of the same names:

```
     # EXTRA_USERS_PARAMS = "\
     # useradd -p '' tester; \
     # groupadd developers; \
     # userdel nobody; \
     # groupdel -g video; \
     # groupmod -g 1020 developers; \
     # usermod -s /bin/sh tester; \
     # "

```
</dd>

</dl>

### F

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FEATURE_PACKAGES[¶][2446]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Defines one or more packages to include in an image when a specific item is included in[`IMAGE_FEATURES`][2447]. When setting the value, `FEATURE_PACKAGES` should have the name of the feature item as an override. Here is an example:

```
     FEATURE_PACKAGES_widget = "package1 package2"

```

In this example, if "widget" were added to `IMAGE_FEATURES`,  _`package1`_  and  _`package2`_  would be included in the image.

### Note

Packages installed by features defined through `FEATURE_PACKAGES` are often package groups. While similarly named, you should not confuse the`FEATURE_PACKAGES` variable with package groups, which are discussed elsewhere in the documentation.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FEED_DEPLOYDIR_BASE_URI[¶][2448]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Points to the base URL of the server and location within the document-root that provides the metadata and packages required by OPKG to support runtime package management of IPK packages. You set this variable in your `local.conf` file.

Consider the following example:

```
     FEED_DEPLOYDIR_BASE_URI = "http://192.168.7.1/BOARD-dir"

```

This example assumes you are serving your packages over HTTP and your databases are located in a directory named `BOARD-dir`, which is underneath your HTTP server's document-root. In this case, the OpenEmbedded build system generates a set of configuration files for you in your target that work with the feed.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FILES[¶][2449]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The list of files and directories that are placed in a package. The [`PACKAGES`][2450] variable lists the packages generated by a recipe.

To use the `FILES` variable, provide a package name override that identifies the resulting package. Then, provide a space-separated list of files or paths that identify the files you want included as part of the resulting package. Here is an example:

```
     FILES_${PN} += "${bindir}/mydir1 ${bindir}/mydir2/myfile"

```

### Note

When specifying paths as part of the `FILES` variable, it is good practice to use appropriate path variables. For example, use `${sysconfdir}` rather than `/etc`, or`${bindir}` rather than `/usr/bin`. You can find a list of these variables at the top of the `meta/conf/bitbake.conf` file in the [Source Directory][2451]. You will also find the default values of the various `FILES_*` variables in this file.

If some of the files you provide with the `FILES` variable are editable and you know they should not be overwritten during the package update process by the Package Management System (PMS), you can identify these files so that the PMS will not overwrite them. See the [`CONFFILES`][2452] variable for information on how to identify these files to the PMS.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FILES_SOLIBSDEV[¶][2453]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Defines the file specification to match [`SOLIBSDEV`][2454]. In other words, `FILES_SOLIBSDEV` defines the full path name of the development symbolic link (symlink) for shared libraries on the target platform.

The following statement from the `bitbake.conf` shows how it is set:

```
     FILES_SOLIBSDEV ?= "${base_libdir}/lib*${SOLIBSDEV} ${libdir}/lib*${SOLIBSDEV}"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FILESEXTRAPATHS[¶][2455]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Extends the search path the OpenEmbedded build system uses when looking for files and patches as it processes recipes and append files. The default directories BitBake uses when it processes recipes are initially defined by the [`FILESPATH`][2456] variable. You can extend `FILESPATH` variable by using `FILESEXTRAPATHS`.

Best practices dictate that you accomplish this by using `FILESEXTRAPATHS` from within a `.bbappend`file and that you prepend paths as follows:

```
     FILESEXTRAPATHS_prepend := "${THISDIR}/${PN}:"

```

In the above example, the build system first looks for files in a directory that has the same name as the corresponding append file.

### Note

When extending `FILESEXTRAPATHS`, be sure to use the immediate expansion (`:=`) operator. Immediate expansion makes sure that BitBake evaluates [`THISDIR`][1499] at the time the directive is encountered rather than at some later time when expansion might result in a directory that does not contain the files you need.

Also, include the trailing separating colon character if you are prepending. The trailing colon character is necessary because you are directing BitBake to extend the path by prepending directories to the search path.

Here is another common use:

```
     FILESEXTRAPATHS_prepend := "${THISDIR}/files:"

```

In this example, the build system extends the `FILESPATH` variable to include a directory named `files` that is in the same directory as the corresponding append file.

Here is a final example that specifically adds three paths:

```
     FILESEXTRAPATHS_prepend := "path_1:path_2:path_3:"

```

By prepending paths in `.bbappend` files, you allow multiple append files that reside in different layers but are used for the same recipe to correctly extend the path.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FILESOVERRIDES[¶][2457]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A subset of [`OVERRIDES`][2458] used by the OpenEmbedded build system for creating [`FILESPATH`][2459]. You can find more information on how overrides are handled in the [BitBake Manual][2460].

By default, the `FILESOVERRIDES` variable is defined as:

```
     FILESOVERRIDES = "${TRANSLATED_TARGET_ARCH}:${MACHINEOVERRIDES}:${DISTROOVERRIDES}"

```

### Note

Do not hand-edit the `FILESOVERRIDES` variable. The values match up with expected overrides and are used in an expected manner by the build system.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FILESPATH[¶][2461]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The default set of directories the OpenEmbedded build system uses when searching for patches and files. During the build process, BitBake searches each directory in `FILESPATH` in the specified order when looking for files and patches specified by each `file://` URI in a recipe.

The default value for the `FILESPATH` variable is defined in the `base.bbclass` class found in `meta/classes` in the [Source Directory][2462]:

```
     FILESPATH = "${@base_set_filespath(["${FILE_DIRNAME}/${BP}", \
        "${FILE_DIRNAME}/${BPN}", "${FILE_DIRNAME}/files"], d)}"

```

### Note

Do not hand-edit the `FILESPATH` variable. If you want the build system to look in directories other than the defaults, extend the `FILESPATH` variable by using the[`FILESEXTRAPATHS`][2463] variable.

Be aware that the default `FILESPATH` directories do not map to directories in custom layers where append files (`.bbappend`) are used. If you want the build system to find patches or files that reside with your append files, you need to extend the `FILESPATH` variable by using the [`FILESEXTRAPATHS`][2464]variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FILESYSTEM_PERMS_TABLES[¶][2465]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Allows you to define your own file permissions settings table as part of your configuration for the packaging process. For example, suppose you need a consistent set of custom permissions for a set of groups and users across an entire work project. It is best to do this in the packages themselves but this is not always possible.

By default, the OpenEmbedded build system uses the `fs-perms.txt`, which is located in the `meta/files` folder in the [Source Directory][2466]. If you create your own file permissions setting table, you should place it in your layer or the distro's layer.

You define the `FILESYSTEM_PERMS_TABLES` variable in the `conf/local.conf` file, which is found in the [Build Directory][2467], to point to your custom `fs-perms.txt`. You can specify more than a single file permissions setting table. The paths you specify to these files must be defined within the [`BBPATH`][2468]variable.

For guidance on how to create your own file permissions settings table file, examine the existing `fs-perms.txt`.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FONT_EXTRA_RDEPENDS[¶][2469]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`fontcache`][2470] class, this variable specifies the runtime dependencies for font packages. By default, the `FONT_EXTRA_RDEPENDS` is set to "fontconfig-utils".

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FONT_PACKAGES[¶][2471]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`fontcache`][2472] class, this variable identifies packages containing font files that need to be cached by Fontconfig. By default, the `fontcache` class assumes that fonts are in the recipe's main package (i.e. `${`[`PN`][2473]`}`). Use this variable if fonts you need are in a package other than that main package.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FORCE_RO_REMOVE[¶][2474]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Forces the removal of the packages listed in `ROOTFS_RO_UNNEEDED` during the generation of the root filesystem.

Set the variable to "1" to force the removal of these packages.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">FULL_OPTIMIZATION[¶][2475]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The options to pass in `[TARGET_CFLAGS][1500]` and `[CFLAGS][1501]` when compiling an optimized system. This variable defaults to "-O2 -pipe ${DEBUG_FLAGS}".

</dd>

</dl>

### G

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">GDB[¶][2476]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The minimal command and arguments to run the GNU Debugger.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">GITDIR[¶][2477]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The directory in which a local copy of a Git repository is stored when it is cloned.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">GLIBC_GENERATE_LOCALES[¶][2478]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the list of GLIBC locales to generate should you not wish generate all LIBC locals, which can be time consuming.

### Note

If you specifically remove the locale `en_US.UTF-8`, you must set [`IMAGE_LINGUAS`][2479]appropriately.

You can set `GLIBC_GENERATE_LOCALES` in your `local.conf` file. By default, all locales are generated.

```
      GLIBC_GENERATE_LOCALES = "en_GB.UTF-8 en_US.UTF-8"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">GROUPADD_PARAM[¶][2480]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`useradd`][2481] class, this variable specifies for a package what parameters should be passed to the `groupadd` command if you wish to add a group to the system when the package is installed.

Here is an example from the `dbus` recipe:

```
     GROUPADD_PARAM_${PN} = "-r netdev"

```

For information on the standard Linux shell command `groupadd`, see[http://linux.die.net/man/8/groupadd][2482].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">GROUPMEMS_PARAM[¶][2483]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`useradd`][2484] class, this variable specifies for a package what parameters should be passed to the `groupmems` command if you wish to modify the members of a group when the package is installed.

For information on the standard Linux shell command `groupmems`, see[http://linux.die.net/man/8/groupmems][2485].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">GRUB_GFXSERIAL[¶][2486]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Configures the GNU GRand Unified Bootloader (GRUB) to have graphics and serial in the boot menu. Set this variable to "1" in your `local.conf` or distribution configuration file to enable graphics and serial in the menu.

See the [`grub-efi`][2487] class for more information on how this variable is used.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">GRUB_OPTS[¶][2488]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Additional options to add to the GNU GRand Unified Bootloader (GRUB) configuration. Use a semi-colon character (`;`) to separate multiple options.

The `GRUB_OPTS` variable is optional. See the [`grub-efi`][2489] class for more information on how this variable is used.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">GRUB_TIMEOUT[¶][2490]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the timeout before executing the default `LABEL` in the GNU GRand Unified Bootloader (GRUB).

The `GRUB_TIMEOUT` variable is optional. See the [`grub-efi`][2491] class for more information on how this variable is used.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">GTKIMMODULES_PACKAGES[¶][2492]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`gtk-immodules-cache`][2493] class, this variable specifies the packages that contain the GTK+ input method modules being installed when the modules are in packages other than the main package.

</dd>

</dl>

### H

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">HOMEPAGE[¶][2494]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Website where more information about the software the recipe is building can be found.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">HOST_ARCH[¶][2495]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The name of the target architecture, which is normally the same as [`TARGET_ARCH`][2496]. The OpenEmbedded build system supports many architectures. Here is an example list of architectures supported. This list is by no means complete as the architecture is configurable:

```
     arm
     i586
     x86_64
     powerpc
     powerpc64
     mips
     mipsel

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">HOST_CC_ARCH[¶][2497]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies architecture-specific compiler flags that are passed to the C compiler.

Default initialization for `HOST_CC_ARCH` varies depending on what is being built:

*   [`TARGET_CC_ARCH`][77] when building for the target

*   `BUILD_CC_ARCH` when building for the build host (i.e. `-native`)

*   `BUILDSDK_CC_ARCH` when building for an SDK (i.e. `nativesdk-`)

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">HOST_OS[¶][2498]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the name of the target operating system, which is normally the same as the [`TARGET_OS`][2499]. The variable can be set to "linux" for `glibc`-based systems and to "linux-uclibc" for `uclibc`. For ARM/EABI targets, there are also "linux-gnueabi" and "linux-uclibc-gnueabi" values possible.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">HOST_PREFIX[¶][2500]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the prefix for the cross-compile toolchain. `HOST_PREFIX` is normally the same as[`TARGET_PREFIX`][2501].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">HOST_SYS[¶][2502]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the system, including the architecture and the operating system, for which the build is occurring in the context of the current recipe.

The OpenEmbedded build system automatically sets this variable based on [`HOST_ARCH`][2503],[`HOST_VENDOR`][2504], and [`HOST_OS`][2505] variables.

### Note

You do not need to set the variable yourself.

Consider these two examples:

*   Given a native recipe on a 32-bit x86 machine running Linux, the value is "i686-linux".

*   Given a recipe being built for a little-endian MIPS target running Linux, the value might be "mipsel-linux".

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">HOSTTOOLS[¶][2506]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A space-separated list (filter) of tools on the build host that should be allowed to be called from within build tasks. Using this filter helps reduce the possibility of host contamination. If a tool specified in the value of `HOSTTOOLS` is not found on the build host, the OpenEmbedded build system produces an error and the build is not started.

For additional information, see [`HOSTTOOLS_NONFATAL`][2507].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">HOSTTOOLS_NONFATAL[¶][2508]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A space-separated list (filter) of tools on the build host that should be allowed to be called from within build tasks. Using this filter helps reduce the possibility of host contamination. Unlike[`HOSTTOOLS`][2509], the OpenEmbedded build system does not produce and error if a tool specified in the value of `HOSTTOOLS_NONFATAL` is not found on the build host. Thus, you can use `HOSTTOOLS_NONFATAL` to filter optional host tools.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">HOST_VENDOR[¶][2510]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the name of the vendor. `HOST_VENDOR` is normally the same as [`TARGET_VENDOR`][2511].

</dd>

</dl>

### I

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">ICECC_DISABLED[¶][2512]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Disables or enables the `icecc` (Icecream) function. For more information on this function and best practices for using this variable, see the "[`icecc.bbclass`][2513]" section.

Setting this variable to "1" in your `local.conf` disables the function:

```
     ICECC_DISABLED ??= "1"

```

To enable the function, set the variable as follows:

```
     ICECC_DISABLED = ""

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">ICECC_ENV_EXEC[¶][2514]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Points to the `icecc-create-env` script that you provide. This variable is used by the [`icecc`][2515] class. You set this variable in your `local.conf` file.

If you do not point to a script that you provide, the OpenEmbedded build system uses the default script provided by the `icecc-create-env.bb` recipe, which is a modified version and not the one that comes with `icecc`.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">ICECC_PARALLEL_MAKE[¶][2516]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Extra options passed to the `make` command during the [`do_compile`][2517] task that specify parallel compilation. This variable usually takes the form of "-j  _`x`_ ", where  _`x`_  represents the maximum number of parallel threads `make` can run.

### Note

The options passed affect builds on all enabled machines on the network, which are machines running the `iceccd` daemon.

If your enabled machines support multiple cores, coming up with the maximum number of parallel threads that gives you the best performance could take some experimentation since machine speed, network lag, available memory, and existing machine loads can all affect build time. Consequently, unlike the [`PARALLEL_MAKE`][2518] variable, there is no rule-of-thumb for setting`ICECC_PARALLEL_MAKE` to achieve optimal performance.

If you do not set `ICECC_PARALLEL_MAKE`, the build system does not use it (i.e. the system does not detect and assign the number of cores as is done with `PARALLEL_MAKE`).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">ICECC_PATH[¶][2519]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The location of the `icecc` binary. You can set this variable in your `local.conf` file. If your `local.conf` file does not define this variable, the [`icecc`][2520] class attempts to define it by locating `icecc`using `which`.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">ICECC_USER_CLASS_BL[¶][2521]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Identifies user classes that you do not want the Icecream distributed compile support to consider. This variable is used by the [`icecc`][2522] class. You set this variable in your `local.conf` file.

When you list classes using this variable, you are "blacklisting" them from distributed compilation across remote hosts. Any classes you list will be distributed and compiled locally.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">ICECC_USER_PACKAGE_BL[¶][2523]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Identifies user recipes that you do not want the Icecream distributed compile support to consider. This variable is used by the [`icecc`][2524] class. You set this variable in your `local.conf` file.

When you list packages using this variable, you are "blacklisting" them from distributed compilation across remote hosts. Any packages you list will be distributed and compiled locally.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">ICECC_USER_PACKAGE_WL[¶][2525]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Identifies user recipes that use an empty [`PARALLEL_MAKE`][2526] variable that you want to force remote distributed compilation on using the Icecream distributed compile support. This variable is used by the [`icecc`][2527] class. You set this variable in your `local.conf` file.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_BASENAME[¶][2528]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The base name of image output files. This variable defaults to the recipe name (`${`[`PN`][2529]`}`).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_BOOT_FILES[¶][2530]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A space-separated list of files installed into the boot partition when preparing an image using the`wic` tool with the `bootimg-partition` source plugin. By default, the files are installed under the same name as the source files. To change the installed name, separate it from the original name with a semi-colon (;). Source files need to be located in [`DEPLOY_DIR_IMAGE`][2531]. Here are two examples:

```
     IMAGE_BOOT_FILES = "u-boot.img uImage;kernel"
     IMAGE_BOOT_FILES = "u-boot.${UBOOT_SUFFIX} ${KERNEL_IMAGETYPE}"

```

Alternatively, source files can be picked up using a glob pattern. In this case, the destination file will have the same name as the base name of the source file path. To install files into a directory within the target location, pass its name after a semi-colon (;). Here are two examples:

```
     IMAGE_BOOT_FILES = "bcm2835-bootfiles/*"
     IMAGE_BOOT_FILES = "bcm2835-bootfiles/*;boot/"

```

The first example installs all files from `${DEPLOY_DIR_IMAGE}/bcm2835-bootfiles` into the root of the target partition. The second example installs the same files into a `boot` directory within the target partition.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_CLASSES[¶][2532]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of classes that all images should inherit. You typically use this variable to specify the list of classes that register the different types of images the OpenEmbedded build system creates.

The default value for `IMAGE_CLASSES` is `image_types`. You can set this variable in your `local.conf`or in a distribution configuration file.

For more information, see `meta/classes/image_types.bbclass` in the [Source Directory][2533].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_CMD[¶][2534]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the command to create the image file for a specific image type, which corresponds to the value set set in [`IMAGE_FSTYPES`][2535], (e.g. `ext3`, `btrfs`, and so forth). When setting this variable, you should use an override for the associated type. Here is an example:

```
     IMAGE_CMD_jffs2 = "mkfs.jffs2 --root=${IMAGE_ROOTFS} \
        --faketime --output=${DEPLOY_DIR_IMAGE}/${IMAGE_NAME}.rootfs.jffs2 \
        ${EXTRA_IMAGECMD}"

```

You typically do not need to set this variable unless you are adding support for a new image type. For more examples on how to set this variable, see the [`image_types`][2536] class file, which is`meta/classes/image_types.bbclass`.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_DEVICE_TABLES[¶][2537]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies one or more files that contain custom device tables that are passed to the `makedevs`command as part of creating an image. These files list basic device nodes that should be created under `/dev` within the image. If `IMAGE_DEVICE_TABLES` is not set, `files/device_table-minimal.txt` is used, which is located by [`BBPATH`][2538]. For details on how you should write device table files, see `meta/files/device_table-minimal.txt` as an example.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_FEATURES[¶][2539]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The primary list of features to include in an image. Typically, you configure this variable in an image recipe. Although you can use this variable from your `local.conf` file, which is found in the [Build Directory][2540], best practices dictate that you do not.

### Note

To enable extra features from outside the image recipe, use the`[EXTRA_IMAGE_FEATURES][1502]` variable.

For a list of image features that ships with the Yocto Project, see the "[Image Features][2541]" section.

For an example that shows how to customize your image by using this variable, see the "[Customizing Images Using Custom `IMAGE_FEATURES` and `EXTRA_IMAGE_FEATURES`][2542]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_FSTYPES[¶][2543]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the formats the OpenEmbedded build system uses during the build when creating the root filesystem. For example, setting `IMAGE_FSTYPES` as follows causes the build system to create root filesystems using two formats: `.ext3` and `.tar.bz2`:

```
     IMAGE_FSTYPES = "ext3 tar.bz2"

```

For the complete list of supported image formats from which you can choose, see [`IMAGE_TYPES`][2544].

### Note

If you add "live" to `IMAGE_FSTYPES` inside an image recipe, be sure that you do so prior to the "inherit image" line of the recipe or the live image will not build.

### Note

Due to the way this variable is processed, it is not possible to update its contents using `_append` or `_prepend`. To add one or more additional options to this variable the `+=` operator must be used.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_INSTALL[¶][2545]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the packages to install into an image. The `IMAGE_INSTALL` variable is a mechanism for an image recipe and you should use it with care to avoid ordering issues.

### Note

When working with an [`core-image-minimal-initramfs`][2546] image, do not use the `IMAGE_INSTALL` variable to specify packages for installation. Instead, use the[`PACKAGE_INSTALL`][2547] variable, which allows the initial RAM filesystem (initramfs) recipe to use a fixed set of packages and not be affected by `IMAGE_INSTALL`. For information on creating an initramfs, see the "[Building an Initial RAM Filesystem (initramfs) Image][2548]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

Image recipes set `IMAGE_INSTALL` to specify the packages to install into an image through`image.bbclass`. Additionally, "helper" classes exist, such as `core-image.bbclass`, that can take`[IMAGE_FEATURES][1503]` lists and turn these into auto-generated entries in `IMAGE_INSTALL` in addition to its default contents.

Using `IMAGE_INSTALL` with the `+=` operator from the `/conf/local.conf` file or from within an image recipe is not recommended as it can cause ordering issues. Since `core-image.bbclass` sets`IMAGE_INSTALL` to a default value using the `?=` operator, using a `+=` operation against`IMAGE_INSTALL` will result in unexpected behavior when used in `conf/local.conf`. Furthermore, the same operation from within an image recipe may or may not succeed depending on the specific situation. In both these cases, the behavior is contrary to how most users expect the `+=` operator to work.

When you use this variable, it is best to use it as follows:

```
     IMAGE_INSTALL_append = " package-name"

```

Be sure to include the space between the quotation character and the start of the package name or names.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_LINGUAS[¶][2549]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the list of locales to install into the image during the root filesystem construction process. The OpenEmbedded build system automatically splits locale files, which are used for localization, into separate packages. Setting the `IMAGE_LINGUAS` variable ensures that any locale packages that correspond to packages already selected for installation into the image are also installed. Here is an example:

```
     IMAGE_LINGUAS = "pt-br de-de"

```

In this example, the build system ensures any Brazilian Portuguese and German locale files that correspond to packages in the image are installed (i.e. `*-locale-pt-br` and `*-locale-de-de` as well as `*-locale-pt` and `*-locale-de`, since some software packages only provide locale files by language and not by country-specific language).

See the [`GLIBC_GENERATE_LOCALES`][2550] variable for information on generating GLIBC locales.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_MANIFEST[¶][2551]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The manifest file for the image. This file lists all the installed packages that make up the image. The file contains package information on a line-per-package basis as follows:

```
     packagename packagearch version

```

The [`image`][2552] class defines the manifest file as follows:

```
     IMAGE_MANIFEST = "${DEPLOY_DIR_IMAGE}/${IMAGE_NAME}.rootfs.manifest"

```

The location is derived using the [`DEPLOY_DIR_IMAGE`][2553] and [`IMAGE_NAME`][2554] variables. You can find information on how the image is created in the "[Image Generation][2555]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_NAME[¶][2556]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The name of the output image files minus the extension. This variable is derived using the[`IMAGE_BASENAME`][2557], [`MACHINE`][2558], and [`DATETIME`][2559] variables:

```
     IMAGE_NAME = "${IMAGE_BASENAME}-${MACHINE}-${DATETIME}"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_OVERHEAD_FACTOR[¶][2560]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Defines a multiplier that the build system applies to the initial image size for cases when the multiplier times the returned disk usage value for the image is greater than the sum of`[IMAGE_ROOTFS_SIZE][1504]` and `[IMAGE_ROOTFS_EXTRA_SPACE][1505]`. The result of the multiplier applied to the initial image size creates free disk space in the image as overhead. By default, the build process uses a multiplier of 1.3 for this variable. This default value results in 30% free disk space added to the image when this method is used to determine the final generated image size. You should be aware that post install scripts and the package management system uses disk space inside this overhead area. Consequently, the multiplier does not produce an image with all the theoretical free disk space. See `[IMAGE_ROOTFS_SIZE][1506]` for information on how the build system determines the overall image size.

The default 30% free disk space typically gives the image enough room to boot and allows for basic post installs while still leaving a small amount of free disk space. If 30% free space is inadequate, you can increase the default value. For example, the following setting gives you 50% free space added to the image:

```
     IMAGE_OVERHEAD_FACTOR = "1.5"

```

Alternatively, you can ensure a specific amount of free disk space is added to the image by using the `[IMAGE_ROOTFS_EXTRA_SPACE][1507]` variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_PKGTYPE[¶][2561]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Defines the package type (DEB, RPM, IPK, or TAR) used by the OpenEmbedded build system. The variable is defined appropriately by the [`package_deb`][2562], [`package_rpm`][2563], [`package_ipk`][2564], or [`package_tar`][2565]class.

### Warning

The `package_tar` class is broken and is not supported. It is recommended that you do not use it.

The [`populate_sdk_*`][2566] and [`image`][2567] classes use the `IMAGE_PKGTYPE` for packaging up images and SDKs.

You should not set the `IMAGE_PKGTYPE` manually. Rather, the variable is set indirectly through the appropriate [`package_*`][2568] class using the [`PACKAGE_CLASSES`][2569] variable. The OpenEmbedded build system uses the first package type (e.g. DEB, RPM, or IPK) that appears with the variable

### Note

Files using the `.tar` format are never used as a substitute packaging format for DEB, RPM, and IPK formatted files for your image or SDK.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_POSTPROCESS_COMMAND[¶][2570]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of functions to call once the OpenEmbedded build system has created the final image output files. You can specify functions separated by semicolons:

```
     IMAGE_POSTPROCESS_COMMAND += "function; ... "

```

If you need to pass the root filesystem path to a command within the function, you can use`${IMAGE_ROOTFS}`, which points to the directory that becomes the root filesystem image. See the[`IMAGE_ROOTFS`][2571] variable for more information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_PREPROCESS_COMMAND[¶][2572]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of functions to call before the OpenEmbedded build system has created the final image output files. You can specify functions separated by semicolons:

```
     IMAGE_PREPROCESS_COMMAND += "function; ... "

```

If you need to pass the root filesystem path to a command within the function, you can use`${IMAGE_ROOTFS}`, which points to the directory that becomes the root filesystem image. See the[`IMAGE_ROOTFS`][2573] variable for more information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_ROOTFS[¶][2574]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The location of the root filesystem while it is under construction (i.e. during the [`do_rootfs`][2575] task). This variable is not configurable. Do not change it.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_ROOTFS_ALIGNMENT[¶][2576]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the alignment for the output image file in Kbytes. If the size of the image is not a multiple of this value, then the size is rounded up to the nearest multiple of the value. The default value is "1". See [`IMAGE_ROOTFS_SIZE`][2577] for additional information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_ROOTFS_EXTRA_SPACE[¶][2578]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Defines additional free disk space created in the image in Kbytes. By default, this variable is set to "0". This free disk space is added to the image after the build system determines the image size as described in `[IMAGE_ROOTFS_SIZE][1508]`.

This variable is particularly useful when you want to ensure that a specific amount of free disk space is available on a device after an image is installed and running. For example, to be sure 5 Gbytes of free disk space is available, set the variable as follows:

```
     IMAGE_ROOTFS_EXTRA_SPACE = "5242880"

```

For example, the Yocto Project Build Appliance specifically requests 40 Gbytes of extra space with the line:

```
     IMAGE_ROOTFS_EXTRA_SPACE = "41943040"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_ROOTFS_SIZE[¶][2579]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Defines the size in Kbytes for the generated image. The OpenEmbedded build system determines the final size for the generated image using an algorithm that takes into account the initial disk space used for the generated image, a requested size for the image, and requested additional free disk space to be added to the image. Programatically, the build system determines the final size of the generated image as follows:

```
    if (image-du * overhead) < rootfs-size:
	internal-rootfs-size = rootfs-size + xspace
    else:
	internal-rootfs-size = (image-du * overhead) + xspace

    where:

      image-du = Returned value of the du command on
                 the image.

      overhead = IMAGE_OVERHEAD_FACTOR

      rootfs-size = IMAGE_ROOTFS_SIZE

      internal-rootfs-size = Initial root filesystem
                             size before any modifications.

      xspace = IMAGE_ROOTFS_EXTRA_SPACE

```

See the [`IMAGE_OVERHEAD_FACTOR`][2580] and [`IMAGE_ROOTFS_EXTRA_SPACE`][2581] variables for related information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_TYPEDEP[¶][2582]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a dependency from one image type on another. Here is an example from the [`image-live`][2583]class:

```
     IMAGE_TYPEDEP_live = "ext3"

```

In the previous example, the variable ensures that when "live" is listed with the [`IMAGE_FSTYPES`][2584]variable, the OpenEmbedded build system produces an `ext3` image first since one of the components of the live image is an `ext3` formatted partition containing the root filesystem.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IMAGE_TYPES[¶][2585]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the complete list of supported image types by default:

```
     btrfs
     cpio
     cpio.gz
     cpio.lz4
     cpio.lzma
     cpio.xz
     cramfs
     elf
     ext2
     ext2.bz2
     ext2.gz
     ext2.lzma
     ext3
     ext3.gz
     ext4
     ext4.gz
     hdddirect
     hddimg
     iso
     jffs2
     jffs2.sum
     multiubi
     qcow2
     squashfs
     squashfs-lzo
     squashfs-xz
     tar
     tar.bz2
     tar.gz
     tar.lz4
     tar.xz
     ubi
     ubifs
     vdi
     vmdk
     wic
     wic.bz2
     wic.gz
     wic.lzma

```

For more information about these types of images, see `meta/classes/image_types*.bbclass` in the [Source Directory][2586].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INC_PR[¶][2587]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Helps define the recipe revision for recipes that share a common `include` file. You can think of this variable as part of the recipe revision as set from within an include file.

Suppose, for example, you have a set of recipes that are used across several projects. And, within each of those recipes the revision (its [`PR`][2588] value) is set accordingly. In this case, when the revision of those recipes changes, the burden is on you to find all those recipes and be sure that they get changed to reflect the updated version of the recipe. In this scenario, it can get complicated when recipes that are used in many places and provide common functionality are upgraded to a new revision.

A more efficient way of dealing with this situation is to set the `INC_PR` variable inside the `include`files that the recipes share and then expand the `INC_PR` variable within the recipes to help define the recipe revision.

The following provides an example that shows how to use the `INC_PR` variable given a common `include` file that defines the variable. Once the variable is defined in the `include` file, you can use the variable to set the `PR` values in each recipe. You will notice that when you set a recipe's `PR` you can provide more granular revisioning by appending values to the `INC_PR` variable:

```
recipes-graphics/xorg-font/xorg-font-common.inc:INC_PR = "r2"
recipes-graphics/xorg-font/encodings_1.0.4.bb:PR = "${INC_PR}.1"
recipes-graphics/xorg-font/font-util_1.3.0.bb:PR = "${INC_PR}.0"
recipes-graphics/xorg-font/font-alias_1.0.3.bb:PR = "${INC_PR}.3"

```

The first line of the example establishes the baseline revision to be used for all recipes that use the`include` file. The remaining lines in the example are from individual recipes and show how the `PR`value is set.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INCOMPATIBLE_LICENSE[¶][2589]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a space-separated list of license names (as they would appear in [`LICENSE`][2590]) that should be excluded from the build. Recipes that provide no alternatives to listed incompatible licenses are not built. Packages that are individually licensed with the specified incompatible licenses will be deleted.

### Note

This functionality is only regularly tested using the following setting:
```
     INCOMPATIBLE_LICENSE = "GPL-3.0 LGPL-3.0 AGPL-3.0"

```
Although you can use other settings, you might be required to remove dependencies on or provide alternatives to components that are required to produce a functional system image.</dd>
