<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INHERIT[¶][2591]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Causes the named class or classes to be inherited globally. Anonymous functions in the class or classes are not executed for the base configuration and in each individual recipe. The OpenEmbedded build system ignores changes to `INHERIT` in individual recipes.

For more information on `INHERIT`, see the "[`INHERIT` Configuration Directive][2592]" section in the Yocto Project Bitbake User Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INHERIT_DISTRO[¶][2593]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Lists classes that will be inherited at the distribution level. It is unlikely that you want to edit this variable.

The default value of the variable is set as follows in the `meta/conf/distro/defaultsetup.conf` file:

```
     INHERIT_DISTRO ?= "debian devshell sstate license"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INHIBIT_DEFAULT_DEPS[¶][2594]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Prevents the default dependencies, namely the C compiler and standard C library (libc), from being added to [`DEPENDS`][2595]. This variable is usually used within recipes that do not require any compilation using the C compiler.

Set the variable to "1" to prevent the default dependencies from being added.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INHIBIT_PACKAGE_DEBUG_SPLIT[¶][2596]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Prevents the OpenEmbedded build system from splitting out debug information during packaging. By default, the build system splits out debugging information during the [`do_package`][2597] task. For more information on how debug information is split out, see the [`PACKAGE_DEBUG_SPLIT_STYLE`][2598] variable.

To prevent the build system from splitting out debug information during packaging, set the`INHIBIT_PACKAGE_DEBUG_SPLIT` variable as follows:

```
     INHIBIT_PACKAGE_DEBUG_SPLIT = "1"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INHIBIT_PACKAGE_STRIP[¶][2599]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

If set to "1", causes the build to not strip binaries in resulting packages and prevents the `-dbg`package from containing the source files.

By default, the OpenEmbedded build system strips binaries and puts the debugging symbols into`${`[`PN`][2600]`}-dbg`. Consequently, you should not set `INHIBIT_PACKAGE_STRIP` when you plan to debug in general.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INITRAMFS_FSTYPES[¶][2601]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Defines the format for the output image of an initial RAM filesystem (initramfs), which is used during boot. Supported formats are the same as those supported by the [`IMAGE_FSTYPES`][2602] variable.

The default value of this variable, which is set in the `meta/conf/bitbake.conf` configuration file in the [Source Directory][2603], is "cpio.gz". The Linux kernel's initramfs mechanism, as opposed to the initial RAM filesystem [initrd][2604] mechanism, expects an optionally compressed cpio archive.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INITRAMFS_IMAGE[¶][2605]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the [`PROVIDES`][2606] name of an image recipe that is used to build an initial RAM filesystem (initramfs) image. An initramfs provides a temporary root filesystem used for early system initialization (e.g. loading of modules needed to locate and mount the "real" root filesystem). The specified recipe is added as a dependency of the root filesystem recipe (e.g. `core-image-sato`). See the `meta/recipes-core/images/core-image-minimal-initramfs.bb` recipe in the [Source Directory][2607] for an example initramfs recipe. To select this recipe to provide the initramfs, set `INITRAMFS_IMAGE` to "core-image-minimal-initramfs".

### Note

The initramfs image recipe should set [`IMAGE_FSTYPES`][2608] to [`INITRAMFS_FSTYPES`][2609].

You can also find more information by referencing the`meta/poky/conf/local.conf.sample.extended` configuration file in the [Source Directory][2610], the[`image`][2611] class, and the [`kernel`][2612] class to see how to use the `INITRAMFS_IMAGE` variable.

If `INITRAMFS_IMAGE` is empty, which is the default, then no initramfs is built.

For more information, you can also see the [`INITRAMFS_IMAGE_BUNDLE`][2613] variable, which allows the generated image to be bundled inside the kernel image. Additionally, for information on creating an initramfs, see the "[Building an Initial RAM Filesystem (initramfs) Image][2614]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INITRAMFS_IMAGE_BUNDLE[¶][2615]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Controls whether or not the image recipe specified by [`INITRAMFS_IMAGE`][2616] is run through an extra pass ([`do_bundle_initramfs`][2617]) during kernel compilation in order to build a single binary that contains both the kernel image and the initial RAM filesystem (initramfs) image. This makes use of the [`CONFIG_INITRAMFS_SOURCE`][2618] kernel feature.

### Note

Using an extra compilation pass to bundle the initramfs avoids a circular dependency between the kernel recipe and the initramfs recipe should the initramfs include kernel modules. Should that be the case, the initramfs recipe depends on the kernel for the kernel modules, and the kernel depends on the initramfs recipe since the initramfs is bundled inside the kernel image.

The combined binary is deposited into the `tmp/deploy` directory, which is part of the [Build Directory][2619].

Setting the variable to "1" in a configuration file causes the OpenEmbedded build system to generate a kernel image with the initramfs specified in [`INITRAMFS_IMAGE`][2620] bundled within:

```
     INITRAMFS_IMAGE_BUNDLE = "1"

```

By default, the [`kernel`][2621] class sets this variable to a null string as follows:

```
     INITRAMFS_IMAGE_BUNDLE ?= ""

```

### Note

You must set the `INITRAMFS_IMAGE_BUNDLE` variable in a configuration file. You cannot set the variable in a recipe file.

See the [`local.conf.sample.extended`][2622] file for additional information. Also, for information on creating an initramfs, see the "[Building an Initial RAM Filesystem (initramfs) Image][2623]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INITRD[¶][2624]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Indicates list of filesystem images to concatenate and use as an initial RAM disk (`initrd`).

The `INITRD` variable is an optional variable used with the [`image-live`][2625] class.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INITRD_IMAGE[¶][2626]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When building a "live" bootable image (i.e. when [`IMAGE_FSTYPES`][2627] contains "live"), `INITRD_IMAGE`specifies the image recipe that should be built to provide the initial RAM disk image. The default value is "core-image-minimal-initramfs".

See the [`image-live`][2628] class for more information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INITSCRIPT_NAME[¶][2629]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The filename of the initialization script as installed to `${sysconfdir}/init.d`.

This variable is used in recipes when using `update-rc.d.bbclass`. The variable is mandatory.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INITSCRIPT_PACKAGES[¶][2630]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of the packages that contain initscripts. If multiple packages are specified, you need to append the package name to the other `INITSCRIPT_*` as an override.

This variable is used in recipes when using `update-rc.d.bbclass`. The variable is optional and defaults to the [`PN`][2631] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INITSCRIPT_PARAMS[¶][2632]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the options to pass to `update-rc.d`. Here is an example:

```
     INITSCRIPT_PARAMS = "start 99 5 2 . stop 20 0 1 6 ."

```

In this example, the script has a runlevel of 99, starts the script in initlevels 2 and 5, and stops the script in levels 0, 1 and 6.

The variable's default value is "defaults", which is set in the [`update-rc.d`][2633] class.

The value in `INITSCRIPT_PARAMS` is passed through to the `update-rc.d` command. For more information on valid parameters, please see the `update-rc.d` manual page at[http://www.tin.org/bin/man.cgi?section=8&topic=update-rc.d][2634].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INSANE_SKIP[¶][2635]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the QA checks to skip for a specific package within a recipe. For example, to skip the check for symbolic link `.so` files in the main package of a recipe, add the following to the recipe. The package name override must be used, which in this example is `${PN}`:

```
     INSANE_SKIP_${PN} += "dev-so"

```

See the "[`insane.bbclass`][2636]" section for a list of the valid QA checks you can specify using this variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">INSTALL_TIMEZONE_FILE[¶][2637]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

By default, the `tzdata` recipe packages an `/etc/timezone` file. Set the `INSTALL_TIMEZONE_FILE`variable to "0" at the configuration level to disable this behavior.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">IPK_FEED_URIS[¶][2638]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When the IPK backend is in use and package management is enabled on the target, you can use this variable to set up `opkg` in the target image to point to package feeds on a nominated server. Once the feed is established, you can perform installations or upgrades using the package manager at runtime.

</dd>

</dl>

### K

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KARCH[¶][2639]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Defines the kernel architecture used when assembling the configuration. Architectures supported for this release are:

```
     powerpc
     i386
     x86_64
     arm
     qemu
     mips

```

You define the `KARCH` variable in the [BSP Descriptions][2640].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KBRANCH[¶][2641]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A regular expression used by the build process to explicitly identify the kernel branch that is validated, patched, and configured during a build. You must set this variable to ensure the exact kernel branch you want is being used by the build process.

Values for this variable are set in the kernel's recipe file and the kernel's append file. For example, if you are using the Yocto Project kernel that is based on the Linux 3.14 kernel, the kernel recipe file is the `meta/recipes-kernel/linux/linux-yocto_3.14.bb` file. Following is an example for a kernel recipe file:

```
     KBRANCH ?= "standard/base"

```

This variable is also used from the kernel's append file to identify the kernel branch specific to a particular machine or target hardware. The kernel's append file is located in the BSP layer for a given machine. For example, the kernel append file for the Emenlow BSP is in the `meta-intel` Git repository and is named `meta-emenlow/recipes-kernel/linux/linux-yocto_3.14.bbappend`. Here are the related statements from the append file:

```
     COMPATIBLE_MACHINE_emenlow-noemgd = "emenlow-noemgd"
     KMACHINE_emenlow-noemgd = "emenlow"
     KBRANCH_emenlow-noemgd = "standard/base"
     KERNEL_FEATURES_append_emenlow-noemgd = " features/drm-gma500/drm-gma500.scc"

```

The `KBRANCH` statement identifies the kernel branch to use when building for the Emenlow BSP.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KBUILD_DEFCONFIG[¶][2642]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When used with the [`kernel-yocto`][2643] class, specifies an "in-tree" kernel configuration file for use during a kernel build.

Typically, when using a `defconfig` to configure a kernel during a build, you place the file in your layer in the same manner as you would patch files and configuration fragment files (i.e. "out-of-tree"). However, if you want to use a `defconfig` file that is part of the kernel tree (i.e. "in-tree"), you can use the `KBUILD_DEFCONFIG` variable to point to the `defconfig` file.

To use the variable, set it in the append file for your kernel recipe using the following form:

```
     KBUILD_DEFCONFIG_KMACHINE ?= defconfig_file

```

Here is an example from a "raspberrypi2" `KMACHINE` build that uses a `defconfig` file named "bcm2709_defconfig":

```
     KBUILD_DEFCONFIG_raspberrypi2 = "bcm2709_defconfig"

```

As an alternative, you can use the following within your append file:

```
     KBUILD_DEFCONFIG_pn-linux-yocto ?= defconfig_file

```

For more information on how to use the `KBUILD_DEFCONFIG` variable, see the "[Using an "In-Tree" `defconfig` File][2645]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_ALT_IMAGETYPE[¶][2646]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies an alternate kernel image type for creation in addition to the kernel image type specified using the [`KERNEL_IMAGETYPE`][2647] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_CLASSES[¶][2648]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of classes defining kernel image types that the [`kernel`][2649] class should inherit. You typically append this variable to enable extended image types. An example is the "kernel-fitimage", which enables fitImage support and resides in `meta/classes/kernel-fitimage.bbclass`. You can register custom kernel image types with the `kernel` class using this variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_DEVICETREE[¶][2650]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the name of the generated Linux kernel device tree (i.e. the `.dtb`) file.

### Note

Legacy support exists for specifying the full path to the device tree. However, providing just the `.dtb` file is preferred.

In order to use this variable, you must have the include files in your kernel recipe:

```
     require recipes-kernel/linux/linux-dtb.inc

```

or

```
     require recipes-kernel/linux/linux-yocto.inc

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_EXTRA_ARGS[¶][2651]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies additional `make` command-line arguments the OpenEmbedded build system passes on when compiling the kernel.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_FEATURES[¶][2652]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Includes additional metadata from the Yocto Project kernel Git repository. In the OpenEmbedded build system, the default Board Support Packages (BSPs) [Metadata][2653] is provided through the [`KMACHINE`][2654] and [`KBRANCH`][2655] variables. You can use the `KERNEL_FEATURES` variable to further add metadata for all BSPs.

The metadata you add through this variable includes config fragments and features descriptions, which usually includes patches as well as config fragments. You typically override the `KERNEL_FEATURES` variable for a specific machine. In this way, you can provide validated, but optional, sets of kernel configurations and features.

For example, the following adds `netfilter` to all the Yocto Project kernels and adds sound support to the `qemux86` machine:

```
     # Add netfilter to all linux-yocto kernels
     KERNEL_FEATURES="features/netfilter/netfilter.scc"

     # Add sound support to the qemux86 machine
     KERNEL_FEATURES_append_qemux86=" cfg/sound.scc"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_IMAGE_BASE_NAME[¶][2656]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The base name of the kernel image. This variable is set in the [kernel][2657] class as follows:

```
     KERNEL_IMAGE_BASE_NAME ?= "${PKGE}-${PKGV}-${PKGR}-${MACHINE}-${DATETIME}"

```

See the [`PKGE`][2658], [`PKGV`][2659], [`PKGR`][2660], [`MACHINE`][2661], and [`DATETIME`][2662] variables for additional information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_IMAGE_MAXSIZE[¶][2663]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the maximum size of the kernel image file in kilobytes. If `KERNEL_IMAGE_MAXSIZE` is set, the size of the kernel image file is checked against the set value during the [`do_sizecheck`][2664] task. The task fails if the kernel image file is larger than the setting.

`KERNEL_IMAGE_MAXSIZE` is useful for target devices that have a limited amount of space in which the kernel image must be stored.

By default, this variable is not set, which means the size of the kernel image is not checked.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_IMAGETYPE[¶][2665]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The type of kernel to build for a device, usually set by the machine configuration files and defaults to "zImage". This variable is used when building the kernel and is passed to `make` as the target to build.

If you want to build an alternate kernel image type, use the [`KERNEL_ALT_IMAGETYPE`][2666] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD[¶][2667]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Lists kernel modules that need to be auto-loaded during boot.

### Note

This variable replaces the deprecated [`module_autoload`][2668] variable.

You can use the `KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD` variable anywhere that it can be recognized by the kernel recipe or by an out-of-tree kernel module recipe (e.g. a machine configuration file, a distribution configuration file, an append file for the recipe, or the recipe itself).

Specify it as follows:

```
     KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD += "module_name1 module_name2 module_name3"

```

Including `KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD` causes the OpenEmbedded build system to populate the`/etc/modules-load.d/modname.conf` file with the list of modules to be auto-loaded on boot. The modules appear one-per-line in the file. Here is an example of the most common use case:

```
     KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD += "module_name"

```

For information on how to populate the `modname.conf` file with `modprobe.d` syntax lines, see the[`KERNEL_MODULE_PROBECONF`][2669] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_MODULE_PROBECONF[¶][2670]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Provides a list of modules for which the OpenEmbedded build system expects to find`module_conf_` _`modname`_  values that specify configuration for each of the modules. For information on how to provide those module configurations, see the [`module_conf_*`][2671] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_PATH[¶][2672]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The location of the kernel sources. This variable is set to the value of the [`STAGING_KERNEL_DIR`][2673]within the [`module`][2674] class. For information on how this variable is used, see the "[Incorporating Out-of-Tree Modules][2675]" section.

To help maximize compatibility with out-of-tree drivers used to build modules, the OpenEmbedded build system also recognizes and uses the [`KERNEL_SRC`][2676] variable, which is identical to the`KERNEL_PATH` variable. Both variables are common variables used by external Makefiles to point to the kernel source directory.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_SRC[¶][2677]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The location of the kernel sources. This variable is set to the value of the [`STAGING_KERNEL_DIR`][2678]within the [`module`][2679] class. For information on how this variable is used, see the "[Incorporating Out-of-Tree Modules][2680]" section.

To help maximize compatibility with out-of-tree drivers used to build modules, the OpenEmbedded build system also recognizes and uses the [`KERNEL_PATH`][2681] variable, which is identical to the`KERNEL_SRC` variable. Both variables are common variables used by external Makefiles to point to the kernel source directory.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNEL_VERSION[¶][2682]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the version of the kernel as extracted from `version.h` or `utsrelease.h` within the kernel sources. Effects of setting this variable do not take affect until the kernel has been configured. Consequently, attempting to refer to this variable in contexts prior to configuration will not work.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KERNELDEPMODDEPEND[¶][2683]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies whether the data referenced through [`PKGDATA_DIR`][2684] is needed or not. The `KERNELDEPMODDEPEND` does not control whether or not that data exists, but simply whether or not it is used. If you do not need to use the data, set the `KERNELDEPMODDEPEND` variable in your `initramfs`recipe. Setting the variable there when the data is not needed avoids a potential dependency loop.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KFEATURE_DESCRIPTION[¶][2685]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Provides a short description of a configuration fragment. You use this variable in the `.scc` file that describes a configuration fragment file. Here is the variable used in a file named `smp.scc` to describe SMP being enabled:

```
     define KFEATURE_DESCRIPTION "Enable SMP"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KMACHINE[¶][2686]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The machine as known by the kernel. Sometimes the machine name used by the kernel does not match the machine name used by the OpenEmbedded build system. For example, the machine name that the OpenEmbedded build system understands as `core2-32-intel-common` goes by a different name in the Linux Yocto kernel. The kernel understands that machine as `intel-core2-32`. For cases like these, the `KMACHINE` variable maps the kernel machine name to the OpenEmbedded build system machine name.

These mappings between different names occur in the Yocto Linux Kernel's `meta` branch. As an example take a look in the `common/recipes-kernel/linux/linux-yocto_3.19.bbappend` file:

```
     LINUX_VERSION_core2-32-intel-common = "3.19.0"
     COMPATIBLE_MACHINE_core2-32-intel-common = "${MACHINE}"
     SRCREV_meta_core2-32-intel-common = "8897ef68b30e7426bc1d39895e71fb155d694974"
     SRCREV_machine_core2-32-intel-common = "43b9eced9ba8a57add36af07736344dcc383f711"
     KMACHINE_core2-32-intel-common = "intel-core2-32"
     KBRANCH_core2-32-intel-common = "standard/base"
     KERNEL_FEATURES_append_core2-32-intel-common = "${KERNEL_FEATURES_INTEL_COMMON}"

```

The `KMACHINE` statement says that the kernel understands the machine name as "intel-core2-32". However, the OpenEmbedded build system understands the machine as "core2-32-intel-common".

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">KTYPE[¶][2687]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Defines the kernel type to be used in assembling the configuration. The linux-yocto recipes define "standard", "tiny", and "preempt-rt" kernel types. See the "[Kernel Types][2688]" section in the Yocto Project Linux Kernel Development Manual for more information on kernel types.

You define the `KTYPE` variable in the [BSP Descriptions][2689]. The value you use must match the value used for the [`LINUX_KERNEL_TYPE`][2690] value used by the kernel recipe.

</dd>

</dl>

### L

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LABELS[¶][2691]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Provides a list of targets for automatic configuration.

See the [`grub-efi`][2692] class for more information on how this variable is used.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LAYERDEPENDS[¶][2693]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Lists the layers, separated by spaces, on which this recipe depends. Optionally, you can specify a specific layer version for a dependency by adding it to the end of the layer name. Here is an example:

```
     LAYERDEPENDS_mylayer = "anotherlayer (=3)"

```

In this previous example, version 3 of "anotherlayer" is compared against[`LAYERVERSION`][2694]`_anotherlayer`.

An error is produced if any dependency is missing or the version numbers (if specified) do not match exactly. This variable is used in the `conf/layer.conf` file and must be suffixed with the name of the specific layer (e.g. `LAYERDEPENDS_mylayer`).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LAYERDIR[¶][2695]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When used inside the `layer.conf` configuration file, this variable provides the path of the current layer. This variable is not available outside of `layer.conf` and references are expanded immediately when parsing of the file completes.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LAYERRECOMMENDS[¶][2696]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Lists the layers, separated by spaces, recommended for use with this layer. Optionally, you can specify a specific layer version for a recommendation by adding the version to the end of the layer name. Here is an example:

```
     LAYERRECOMMENDS_mylayer = "anotherlayer (=3)"

```

In this previous example, version 3 of "anotherlayer" is compared against`LAYERVERSION_anotherlayer`.

An error is produced if any dependency is missing or the version numbers (if specified) do not match exactly. This variable is used in the `conf/layer.conf` file and must be suffixed with the name of the specific layer (e.g. `LAYERRECOMMENDS_mylayer`).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LAYERVERSION[¶][2697]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Optionally specifies the version of a layer as a single number. You can use this within [`LAYERDEPENDS`][2698]for another layer in order to depend on a specific version of the layer. This variable is used in the `conf/layer.conf` file and must be suffixed with the name of the specific layer (e.g.`LAYERVERSION_mylayer`).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LD[¶][2699]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The minimal command and arguments used to run the linker.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LDFLAGS[¶][2700]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the flags to pass to the linker. This variable is exported to an environment variable and thus made visible to the software being built during the compilation step.

Default initialization for `LDFLAGS` varies depending on what is being built:

*   [`TARGET_LDFLAGS`][78] when building for the target

*   [`BUILD_LDFLAGS`][79] when building for the build host (i.e. `-native`)

*   [`BUILDSDK_LDFLAGS`][80] when building for an SDK (i.e. `nativesdk-`)

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LEAD_SONAME[¶][2701]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the lead (or primary) compiled library file (`.so`) that the [`debian`][2702] class applies its naming policy to given a recipe that packages multiple libraries.

This variable works in conjunction with the `debian` class.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LIC_FILES_CHKSUM[¶][2703]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Checksums of the license text in the recipe source code.

This variable tracks changes in license text of the source code files. If the license text is changed, it will trigger a build failure, which gives the developer an opportunity to review any license change.

This variable must be defined for all recipes (unless [`LICENSE`][2704] is set to "CLOSED").

For more information, see the "[ Tracking License Changes][2705]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LICENSE[¶][2706]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The list of source licenses for the recipe. Follow these rules:

*   Do not use spaces within individual license names.

*   Separate license names using | (pipe) when there is a choice between licenses.

*   Separate license names using & (ampersand) when multiple licenses exist that cover different parts of the source.

*   You can use spaces between license names.

*   For standard licenses, use the names of the files in `meta/files/common-licenses/` or the[`SPDXLICENSEMAP`][81] flag names defined in `meta/conf/licenses.conf`.

Here are some examples:

```
     LICENSE = "LGPLv2.1 | GPLv3"
     LICENSE = "MPL-1 & LGPLv2.1"
     LICENSE = "GPLv2+"

```

The first example is from the recipes for Qt, which the user may choose to distribute under either the LGPL version 2.1 or GPL version 3\. The second example is from Cairo where two licenses cover different parts of the source code. The final example is from `sysstat`, which presents a single license.

You can also specify licenses on a per-package basis to handle situations where components of the output have different licenses. For example, a piece of software whose code is licensed under GPLv2 but has accompanying documentation licensed under the GNU Free Documentation License 1.2 could be specified as follows:

```
     LICENSE = "GFDL-1.2 & GPLv2"
     LICENSE_${PN} = "GPLv2"
     LICENSE_${PN}-doc = "GFDL-1.2"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LICENSE_CREATE_PACKAGE[¶][2707]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Setting `LICENSE_CREATE_PACKAGE` to "1" causes the OpenEmbedded build system to create an extra package (i.e. `${`[`PN`][2708]`}-lic`) for each recipe and to add those packages to the [`RRECOMMENDS`][2709]`_${PN}`.

The `${PN}-lic` package installs a directory in `/usr/share/licenses` named `${PN}`, which is the recipe's base name, and installs files in that directory that contain license and copyright information (i.e. copies of the appropriate license files from `meta/common-licenses` that match the licenses specified in the [`LICENSE`][2710] variable of the recipe metadata and copies of files marked in[`LIC_FILES_CHKSUM`][2711] as containing license text).

For related information on providing license text, see the [`COPY_LIC_DIRS`][2712] variable, the[`COPY_LIC_MANIFEST`][2713] variable, and the "[Providing License Text][2714]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LICENSE_FLAGS[¶][2715]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies additional flags for a recipe you must whitelist through [`LICENSE_FLAGS_WHITELIST`][2716] in order to allow the recipe to be built. When providing multiple flags, separate them with spaces.

This value is independent of [`LICENSE`][2717] and is typically used to mark recipes that might require additional licenses in order to be used in a commercial product. For more information, see the "[Enabling Commercially Licensed Recipes][2718]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LICENSE_FLAGS_WHITELIST[¶][2719]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Lists license flags that when specified in [`LICENSE_FLAGS`][2720] within a recipe should not prevent that recipe from being built. This practice is otherwise known as "whitelisting" license flags. For more information, see the [Enabling Commercially Licensed Recipes][2721]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LICENSE_PATH[¶][2722]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Path to additional licenses used during the build. By default, the OpenEmbedded build system uses `COMMON_LICENSE_DIR` to define the directory that holds common license text used during the build. The `LICENSE_PATH` variable allows you to extend that location to other areas that have additional licenses:

```
     LICENSE_PATH += "path-to-additional-common-licenses"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LINUX_KERNEL_TYPE[¶][2723]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Defines the kernel type to be used in assembling the configuration. The linux-yocto recipes define "standard", "tiny", and "preempt-rt" kernel types. See the "[Kernel Types][2724]" section in the Yocto Project Linux Kernel Development Manual for more information on kernel types.

If you do not specify a `LINUX_KERNEL_TYPE`, it defaults to "standard". Together with [`KMACHINE`][2725], the `LINUX_KERNEL_TYPE` variable defines the search arguments used by the kernel tools to find the appropriate description within the kernel [Metadata][2726] with which to build out the sources and configuration.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LINUX_VERSION[¶][2727]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The Linux version from `kernel.org` on which the Linux kernel image being built using the OpenEmbedded build system is based. You define this variable in the kernel recipe. For example, the `linux-yocto-3.4.bb` kernel recipe found in `meta/recipes-kernel/linux` defines the variables as follows:

```
     LINUX_VERSION ?= "3.4.24"

```

The `LINUX_VERSION` variable is used to define [`PV`][2728] for the recipe:

```
     PV = "${LINUX_VERSION}+git${SRCPV}"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LINUX_VERSION_EXTENSION[¶][2729]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A string extension compiled into the version string of the Linux kernel built with the OpenEmbedded build system. You define this variable in the kernel recipe. For example, the linux-yocto kernel recipes all define the variable as follows:

```
     LINUX_VERSION_EXTENSION ?= "-yocto-${LINUX_KERNEL_TYPE}"

```

Defining this variable essentially sets the Linux kernel configuration item `CONFIG_LOCALVERSION`, which is visible through the `uname` command. Here is an example that shows the extension assuming it was set as previously shown:

```
     $ uname -r
     3.7.0-rc8-custom

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">LOG_DIR[¶][2731]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the directory to which the OpenEmbedded build system writes overall log files. The default directory is `${TMPDIR}/log`.

For the directory containing logs specific to each task, see the [`T`][2732] variable.

</dd>

</dl>

### M

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MACHINE[¶][2733]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the target device for which the image is built. You define `MACHINE` in the `local.conf` file found in the [Build Directory][2734]. By default, `MACHINE` is set to "qemux86", which is an x86-based architecture machine to be emulated using QEMU:

```
     MACHINE ?= "qemux86"

```

The variable corresponds to a machine configuration file of the same name, through which machine-specific configurations are set. Thus, when `MACHINE` is set to "qemux86" there exists the corresponding `qemux86.conf` machine configuration file, which can be found in the [Source Directory][2735]in `meta/conf/machine`.

The list of machines supported by the Yocto Project as shipped include the following:

```
     MACHINE ?= "qemuarm"
     MACHINE ?= "qemuarm64"
     MACHINE ?= "qemumips"
     MACHINE ?= "qemumips64"
     MACHINE ?= "qemuppc"
     MACHINE ?= "qemux86"
     MACHINE ?= "qemux86-64"
     MACHINE ?= "genericx86"
     MACHINE ?= "genericx86-64"
     MACHINE ?= "beaglebone"
     MACHINE ?= "mpc8315e-rdb"
     MACHINE ?= "edgerouter"

```

The last five are Yocto Project reference hardware boards, which are provided in the `meta-yocto-bsp` layer.

### Note

Adding additional Board Support Package (BSP) layers to your configuration adds new possible settings for `MACHINE`.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MACHINE_ARCH[¶][2736]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the name of the machine-specific architecture. This variable is set automatically from[`MACHINE`][2737] or [`TUNE_PKGARCH`][2738]. You should not hand-edit the `MACHINE_ARCH` variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MACHINE_ESSENTIAL_EXTRA_RDEPENDS[¶][2739]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of required machine-specific packages to install as part of the image being built. The build process depends on these packages being present. Furthermore, because this is a "machine essential" variable, the list of packages are essential for the machine to boot. The impact of this variable affects images based on `packagegroup-core-boot`, including the `core-image-minimal`image.

This variable is similar to the `[MACHINE_ESSENTIAL_EXTRA_RRECOMMENDS][1509]` variable with the exception that the image being built has a build dependency on the variable's list of packages. In other words, the image will not build if a file in this list is not found.

As an example, suppose the machine for which you are building requires `example-init` to be run during boot to initialize the hardware. In this case, you would use the following in the machine's`.conf` configuration file:

```
     MACHINE_ESSENTIAL_EXTRA_RDEPENDS += "example-init"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MACHINE_ESSENTIAL_EXTRA_RRECOMMENDS[¶][2740]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of recommended machine-specific packages to install as part of the image being built. The build process does not depend on these packages being present. However, because this is a "machine essential" variable, the list of packages are essential for the machine to boot. The impact of this variable affects images based on `packagegroup-core-boot`, including the `core-image-minimal` image.

This variable is similar to the `[MACHINE_ESSENTIAL_EXTRA_RDEPENDS][1510]` variable with the exception that the image being built does not have a build dependency on the variable's list of packages. In other words, the image will still build if a package in this list is not found. Typically, this variable is used to handle essential kernel modules, whose functionality may be selected to be built into the kernel rather than as a module, in which case a package will not be produced.

Consider an example where you have a custom kernel where a specific touchscreen driver is required for the machine to be usable. However, the driver can be built as a module or into the kernel depending on the kernel configuration. If the driver is built as a module, you want it to be installed. But, when the driver is built into the kernel, you still want the build to succeed. This variable sets up a "recommends" relationship so that in the latter case, the build will not fail due to the missing package. To accomplish this, assuming the package for the module was called `kernel-module-ab123`, you would use the following in the machine's `.conf` configuration file:

```
     MACHINE_ESSENTIAL_EXTRA_RRECOMMENDS += "kernel-module-ab123"

```

### Note

In this example, the `kernel-module-ab123` recipe needs to explicitly set its[`PACKAGES`][2741] variable to ensure that BitBake does not use the kernel recipe's[`PACKAGES_DYNAMIC`][2742] variable to satisfy the dependency.

Some examples of these machine essentials are flash, screen, keyboard, mouse, or touchscreen drivers (depending on the machine).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MACHINE_EXTRA_RDEPENDS[¶][2743]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of machine-specific packages to install as part of the image being built that are not essential for the machine to boot. However, the build process for more fully-featured images depends on the packages being present.

This variable affects all images based on `packagegroup-base`, which does not include the `core-image-minimal` or `core-image-full-cmdline` images.

The variable is similar to the `[MACHINE_EXTRA_RRECOMMENDS][1511]` variable with the exception that the image being built has a build dependency on the variable's list of packages. In other words, the image will not build if a file in this list is not found.

An example is a machine that has WiFi capability but is not essential for the machine to boot the image. However, if you are building a more fully-featured image, you want to enable the WiFi. The package containing the firmware for the WiFi hardware is always expected to exist, so it is acceptable for the build process to depend upon finding the package. In this case, assuming the package for the firmware was called `wifidriver-firmware`, you would use the following in the`.conf` file for the machine:

```
     MACHINE_EXTRA_RDEPENDS += "wifidriver-firmware"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MACHINE_EXTRA_RRECOMMENDS[¶][2744]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of machine-specific packages to install as part of the image being built that are not essential for booting the machine. The image being built has no build dependency on this list of packages.

This variable affects only images based on `packagegroup-base`, which does not include the `core-image-minimal` or `core-image-full-cmdline` images.

This variable is similar to the `[MACHINE_EXTRA_RDEPENDS][1512]` variable with the exception that the image being built does not have a build dependency on the variable's list of packages. In other words, the image will build if a file in this list is not found.

An example is a machine that has WiFi capability but is not essential For the machine to boot the image. However, if you are building a more fully-featured image, you want to enable WiFi. In this case, the package containing the WiFi kernel module will not be produced if the WiFi driver is built into the kernel, in which case you still want the build to succeed instead of failing as a result of the package not being found. To accomplish this, assuming the package for the module was called`kernel-module-examplewifi`, you would use the following in the `.conf` file for the machine:

```
     MACHINE_EXTRA_RRECOMMENDS += "kernel-module-examplewifi"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MACHINE_FEATURES[¶][2745]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the list of hardware features the [`MACHINE`][2746] is capable of supporting. For related information on enabling features, see the [`DISTRO_FEATURES`][2747], [`COMBINED_FEATURES`][2748], and [`IMAGE_FEATURES`][2749]variables.

For a list of hardware features supported by the Yocto Project as shipped, see the "[Machine Features][2750]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MACHINE_FEATURES_BACKFILL[¶][2751]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Features to be added to `[MACHINE_FEATURES][1513]` if not also present in`[MACHINE_FEATURES_BACKFILL_CONSIDERED][1514]`.

This variable is set in the `meta/conf/bitbake.conf` file. It is not intended to be user-configurable. It is best to just reference the variable to see which machine features are being backfilled for all machine configurations. See the "[Feature backfilling][2752]" section for more information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MACHINE_FEATURES_BACKFILL_CONSIDERED[¶][2753]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Features from `[MACHINE_FEATURES_BACKFILL][1515]` that should not be backfilled (i.e. added to`[MACHINE_FEATURES][1516]`) during the build. See the "[Feature backfilling][2754]" section for more information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MACHINEOVERRIDES[¶][2755]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A colon-separated list of overrides that apply to the current machine. By default, this list includes the value of [`MACHINE`][2756].

You can extend `MACHINEOVERRIDES` to add extra overrides that should apply to a machine. For example, all machines emulated in QEMU (e.g. `qemuarm`, `qemux86`, and so forth) include a file named`meta/conf/machine/include/qemu.inc` that prepends the following override to `MACHINEOVERRIDES`:

```
     MACHINEOVERRIDES =. "qemuall:"

```

This override allows variables to be overriden for all machines emulated in QEMU, like in the following example from the `connman-conf` recipe:

```
     SRC_URI_append_qemuall = "file://wired.config \
                               file://wired-setup \
                              "

```

The underlying mechanism behind `MACHINEOVERRIDES` is simply that it is included in the default value of [`OVERRIDES`][2757].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MAINTAINER[¶][2758]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The email address of the distribution maintainer.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MIRRORS[¶][2759]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies additional paths from which the OpenEmbedded build system gets source code. When the build system searches for source code, it first tries the local download directory. If that location fails, the build system tries locations defined by [`PREMIRRORS`][2760], the upstream source, and then locations specified by `MIRRORS` in that order.

Assuming your distribution ([`DISTRO`][2761]) is "poky", the default value for `MIRRORS` is defined in the`conf/distro/poky.conf` file in the `meta-poky` Git repository.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MLPREFIX[¶][2762]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a prefix has been added to [`PN`][2763] to create a special version of a recipe or package, such as a Multilib version. The variable is used in places where the prefix needs to be added to or removed from a the name (e.g. the [`BPN`][2764] variable). `MLPREFIX` gets set when a prefix has been added to `PN`.

### Note

The "ML" in `MLPREFIX` stands for "MultiLib". This representation is historical and comes from a time when `nativesdk` was a suffix rather than a prefix on the recipe name. When `nativesdk` was turned into a prefix, it made sense to set `MLPREFIX` for it as well.

To help understand when `MLPREFIX` might be needed, consider when [`BBCLASSEXTEND`][2765] is used to provide a `nativesdk` version of a recipe in addition to the target version. If that recipe declares build-time dependencies on tasks in other recipes by using [`DEPENDS`][2766], then a dependency on "foo" will automatically get rewritten to a dependency on "nativesdk-foo". However, dependencies like the following will not get rewritten automatically:

```
     do_foo[depends] += "recipe:do_foo"

```

If you want such a dependency to also get transformed, you can do the following:

```
     do_foo[depends] += "${MLPREFIX}recipe:do_foo"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">module_autoload[¶][2767]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

This variable has been replaced by the `KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD` variable. You should replace all occurrences of `module_autoload` with additions to `KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD`, for example:

```
     module_autoload_rfcomm = "rfcomm"

```

should now be replaced with:

```
     KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD += "rfcomm"

```

See the [`KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD`][2768] variable for more information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">module_conf[¶][2769]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies [`modprobe.d`][2770] syntax lines for inclusion in the `/etc/modprobe.d/modname.conf` file.

You can use this variable anywhere that it can be recognized by the kernel recipe or out-of-tree kernel module recipe (e.g. a machine configuration file, a distribution configuration file, an append file for the recipe, or the recipe itself). If you use this variable, you must also be sure to list the module name in the [`KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD`][2771] variable.

Here is the general syntax:

```
     module_conf_module_name = "modprobe.d-syntax"

```

You must use the kernel module name override.

Run `man modprobe.d` in the shell to find out more information on the exact syntax you want to provide with `module_conf`.

Including `module_conf` causes the OpenEmbedded build system to populate the`/etc/modprobe.d/modname.conf` file with `modprobe.d` syntax lines. Here is an example that adds the options `arg1` and `arg2` to a module named `mymodule`:

```
     module_conf_mymodule = "options mymodule arg1=val1 arg2=val2"

```

For information on how to specify kernel modules to auto-load on boot, see the[`KERNEL_MODULE_AUTOLOAD`][2772] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MODULE_IMAGE_BASE_NAME[¶][2773]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The base name of the kernel modules tarball. This variable is set in the [kernel][2774] class as follows:

```
     MODULE_IMAGE_BASE_NAME ?= "modules-${PKGE}-${PKGV}-${PKGR}-${MACHINE}-${DATETIME}"

```

See the [`PKGE`][2775], [`PKGV`][2776], [`PKGR`][2777], [`MACHINE`][2778], and [`DATETIME`][2779] variables for additional information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MODULE_TARBALL_DEPLOY[¶][2780]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Controls creation of the `modules-*.tgz` file. Set this variable to "0" to disable creation of this file, which contains all of the kernel modules resulting from a kernel build.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">MULTIMACH_TARGET_SYS[¶][2781]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Uniquely identifies the type of the target system for which packages are being built. This variable allows output for different types of target systems to be put into different subdirectories of the same output directory.

The default value of this variable is:

```
     ${PACKAGE_ARCH}${TARGET_VENDOR}-${TARGET_OS}

```

Some classes (e.g. [`cross-canadian`][2782]) modify the `MULTIMACH_TARGET_SYS` value.

See the [`STAMP`][2783] variable for an example. See the [`STAGING_DIR_TARGET`][2784] variable for more information.

</dd>

</dl>

### N

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">NATIVELSBSTRING[¶][2785]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A string identifying the host distribution. Strings consist of the host distributor ID followed by the release, as reported by the `lsb_release` tool or as read from `/etc/lsb-release`. For example, when running a build on Ubuntu 12.10, the value is "Ubuntu-12.10". If this information is unable to be determined, the value resolves to "Unknown".

This variable is used by default to isolate native shared state packages for different distributions (e.g. to avoid problems with `glibc` version incompatibilities). Additionally, the variable is checked against [`SANITY_TESTED_DISTROS`][2786] if that variable is set.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">NM[¶][2787]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The minimal command and arguments to run `nm`.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">NO_RECOMMENDATIONS[¶][2788]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Prevents installation of all "recommended-only" packages. Recommended-only packages are packages installed only through the [`RRECOMMENDS`][2789] variable). Setting the `NO_RECOMMENDATIONS`variable to "1" turns this feature on:

```
     NO_RECOMMENDATIONS = "1"

```

You can set this variable globally in your `local.conf` file or you can attach it to a specific image recipe by using the recipe name override:

```
     NO_RECOMMENDATIONS_pn-target_image = "1"

```

It is important to realize that if you choose to not install packages using this variable and some other packages are dependent on them (i.e. listed in a recipe's [`RDEPENDS`][2790] variable), the OpenEmbedded build system ignores your request and will install the packages to avoid dependency errors.

### Note

Some recommended packages might be required for certain system functionality, such as kernel modules. It is up to you to add packages with the [`IMAGE_INSTALL`][2791]variable.

Support for this variable exists only when using the IPK and RPM packaging backend. Support does not exist for DEB.

See the [`BAD_RECOMMENDATIONS`][2792] and the [`PACKAGE_EXCLUDE`][2793] variables for related information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">NOHDD[¶][2794]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Causes the OpenEmbedded build system to skip building the `.hddimg` image. The `NOHDD` variable is used with the [`image-live`][2795] class. Set the variable to "1" to prevent the `.hddimg` image from being built.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">NOISO[¶][2796]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Causes the OpenEmbedded build system to skip building the ISO image. The `NOISO` variable is used with the [`image-live`][2797] class. Set the variable to "1" to prevent the ISO image from being built. To enable building an ISO image, set the variable to "0".

</dd>

</dl>

### O

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">OBJCOPY[¶][2798]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The minimal command and arguments to run `objcopy`.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">OBJDUMP[¶][2799]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The minimal command and arguments to run `objdump`.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">OE_BINCONFIG_EXTRA_MANGLE[¶][2800]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`binconfig`][2801] class, this variable specifies additional arguments passed to the "sed" command. The sed command alters any paths in configuration scripts that have been set up during compilation. Inheriting this class results in all paths in these scripts being changed to point into the `sysroots/` directory so that all builds that use the script will use the correct directories for the cross compiling layout.

See the `meta/classes/binconfig.bbclass` in the [Source Directory][2802] for details on how this class applies these additional sed command arguments. For general information on the`binconfig.bbclass` class, see the "[Binary Configuration Scripts - `binconfig.bbclass`][2803]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">OE_IMPORTS[¶][2804]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

An internal variable used to tell the OpenEmbedded build system what Python modules to import for every Python function run by the system.

### Note

Do not set this variable. It is for internal use only.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">OE_INIT_ENV_SCRIPT[¶][2805]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The name of the build environment setup script for the purposes of setting up the environment within the extensible SDK. The default value is "oe-init-build-env".

If you use a custom script to set up your build environment, set the `OE_INIT_ENV_SCRIPT` variable to its name.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">OE_TERMINAL[¶][2806]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Controls how the OpenEmbedded build system spawns interactive terminals on the host development system (e.g. using the BitBake command with the `-c devshell` command-line option). For more information, see the "[Using a Development Shell][2807]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

You can use the following values for the `OE_TERMINAL` variable:

```
     auto
     gnome
     xfce
     rxvt
     screen
     konsole
     none

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">OEROOT[¶][2808]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The directory from which the top-level build environment setup script is sourced. The Yocto Project makes two top-level build environment setup scripts available: [`oe-init-build-env`][2809] and [`oe-init-build-env-memres`][2810]. When you run one of these scripts, the `OEROOT` variable resolves to the directory that contains the script.

For additional information on how this variable is used, see the initialization scripts.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">OLDEST_KERNEL[¶][2811]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Declares the oldest version of the Linux kernel that the produced binaries must support. This variable is passed into the build of the Embedded GNU C Library (`glibc`).

The default for this variable comes from the `meta/conf/bitbake.conf` configuration file. You can override this default by setting the variable in a custom distribution configuration file.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">OVERRIDES[¶][2812]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A colon-separated list of overrides that currently apply. Overrides are a BitBake mechanism that allows variables to be selectively overridden at the end of parsing. The set of overrides in `OVERRIDES`represents the "state" during building, which includes the current recipe being built, the machine for which it is being built, and so forth.

As an example, if the string "an-override" appears as an element in the colon-separated list in`OVERRIDES`, then the following assignment will override `FOO` with the value "overridden" at the end of parsing:

```
     FOO_an-override = "overridden"

```

See the "[Conditional Syntax (Overrides)][2813]" section in the BitBake User Manual for more information on the overrides mechanism.

The default value of `OVERRIDES` includes the values of the [`CLASSOVERRIDE`][2814], [`MACHINEOVERRIDES`][2815], and[`DISTROOVERRIDES`][2816] variables. Another important override included by default is `pn-${PN}`. This override allows variables to be set for a single recipe within configuration (`.conf`) files. Here is an example:

```
     FOO_pn-myrecipe = "myrecipe-specific value"

```

### Tip

An easy way to see what overrides apply is to search for `OVERRIDES` in the output of the `bitbake -e` command. See the "[Viewing Variable Values][2817]" section for more information.</dd>

</dl>

### P

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">P[¶][2818]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The recipe name and version. `P` is comprised of the following:

```
     ${PN}-${PV}

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_ARCH[¶][2819]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The architecture of the resulting package or packages.

By default, the value of this variable is set to [`TUNE_PKGARCH`][2820] when building for the target,`BUILD_ARCH` when building for the build host and "${SDK_ARCH}-${SDKPKGSUFFIX}" when building for the SDK. However, if your recipe's output packages are built specific to the target machine rather than general for the architecture of the machine, you should set `PACKAGE_ARCH` to the value of[`MACHINE_ARCH`][2821] in the recipe as follows:

```
     PACKAGE_ARCH = "${MACHINE_ARCH}"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_ARCHS[¶][2822]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of architectures compatible with the target machine. This variable is set automatically and should not normally be hand-edited. Entries are separated using spaces and listed in order of priority. The default value for `PACKAGE_ARCHS` is "all any noarch ${PACKAGE_EXTRA_ARCHS} ${MACHINE_ARCH}".

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_BEFORE_PN[¶][2823]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Enables easily adding packages to `[PACKAGES][1517]` before `${[PN][1518]}` so that those added packages can pick up files that would normally be included in the default package.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_CLASSES[¶][2824]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

This variable, which is set in the `local.conf` configuration file found in the `conf` folder of the [Build Directory][2825], specifies the package manager the OpenEmbedded build system uses when packaging data.

You can provide one or more of the following arguments for the variable:

```
     PACKAGE_CLASSES ?= "package_rpm package_deb package_ipk package_tar"

```

### Warning

While it is a legal option, the `package_tar` class is broken and is not supported. It is recommended that you do not use it.

The build system uses only the first argument in the list as the package manager when creating your image or SDK. However, packages will be created using any additional packaging classes you specify. For example, if you use the following in your `local.conf` file:

```
     PACKAGE_CLASSES ?= "package_ipk"

```

The OpenEmbedded build system uses the IPK package manager to create your image or SDK.

For information on packaging and build performance effects as a result of the package manager in use, see the "[`package.bbclass`][2826]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_DEBUG_SPLIT_STYLE[¶][2827]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Determines how to split up the binary and debug information when creating `*-dbg` packages to be used with the GNU Project Debugger (GDB).

With the `PACKAGE_DEBUG_SPLIT_STYLE` variable, you can control where debug information, which can include or exclude source files, is stored:

*   ".debug": Debug symbol files are placed next to the binary in a `.debug` directory on the target. For example, if a binary is installed into `/bin`, the corresponding debug symbol files are installed in `/bin/.debug`. Source files are placed in `/usr/src/debug`. This is the default behavior.

*   "debug-file-directory": Debug symbol files are placed under `/usr/lib/debug` on the target, and separated by the path from where the binary is installed. For example, if a binary is installed in`/bin`, the corresponding debug symbols are installed in `/usr/lib/debug/bin`. Source files are placed in `/usr/src/debug`.

*   "debug-without-src": The same behavior as ".debug" previously described with the exception that no source files are installed.

You can find out more about debugging using GDB by reading the "[Debugging With the GNU Project Debugger (GDB) Remotely][2828]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_EXCLUDE_COMPLEMENTARY[¶][2829]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Prevents specific packages from being installed when you are installing complementary packages.

You might find that you want to prevent installing certain packages when you are installing complementary packages. For example, if you are using [`IMAGE_FEATURES`][2830] to install `dev-pkgs`, you might not want to install all packages from a particular multilib. If you find yourself in this situation, you can use the `PACKAGE_EXCLUDE_COMPLEMENTARY` variable to specify regular expressions to match the packages you want to exclude.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_EXCLUDE[¶][2831]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Lists packages that should not be installed into an image. For example:

```
     PACKAGE_EXCLUDE = "package_name package_name package_name ..."

```

You can set this variable globally in your `local.conf` file or you can attach it to a specific image recipe by using the recipe name override:

```
     PACKAGE_EXCLUDE_pn-target_image = "package_name"

```

If you choose to not install a package using this variable and some other package is dependent on it (i.e. listed in a recipe's [`RDEPENDS`][2832] variable), the OpenEmbedded build system generates a fatal installation error. Because the build system halts the process with a fatal error, you can use the variable with an iterative development process to remove specific components from a system.

Support for this variable exists only when using the IPK and RPM packaging backend. Support does not exist for DEB.

See the [`NO_RECOMMENDATIONS`][2833] and the [`BAD_RECOMMENDATIONS`][2834] variables for related information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_EXTRA_ARCHS[¶][2835]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the list of architectures compatible with the device CPU. This variable is useful when you build for several different devices that use miscellaneous processors such as XScale and ARM926-EJS.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_FEED_ARCHS[¶][2836]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the package architectures used as part of the package feed URIs during the build. The `PACKAGE_FEED_ARCHS` variable is appended to the final package feed URI, which is constructed using the [`PACKAGE_FEED_URIS`][2837] and [`PACKAGE_FEED_BASE_PATHS`][2838] variables.

Consider the following example where the `PACKAGE_FEED_URIS`, `PACKAGE_FEED_BASE_PATHS`, and`PACKAGE_FEED_ARCHS` variables are defined in your `local.conf` file:

```
     PACKAGE_FEED_URIS = "https://example.com/packagerepos/release \
                          https://example.com/packagerepos/updates"
     PACKAGE_FEED_BASE_PATHS = "rpm rpm-dev"
     PACKAGE_FEED_ARCHS = "all core2-64"

```

Given these settings, the resulting package feeds are as follows:

```
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm/core2-64
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm-dev/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm-dev/core2-64
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm/core2-64
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm-dev/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm-dev/core2-64

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_FEED_BASE_PATHS[¶][2839]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the base path used when constructing package feed URIs. The `PACKAGE_FEED_BASE_PATHS`variable makes up the middle portion of a package feed URI used by the OpenEmbedded build system. The base path lies between the [`PACKAGE_FEED_URIS`][2840] and [`PACKAGE_FEED_ARCHS`][2841] variables.

Consider the following example where the `PACKAGE_FEED_URIS`, `PACKAGE_FEED_BASE_PATHS`, and`PACKAGE_FEED_ARCHS` variables are defined in your `local.conf` file:

```
     PACKAGE_FEED_URIS = "https://example.com/packagerepos/release \
                          https://example.com/packagerepos/updates"
     PACKAGE_FEED_BASE_PATHS = "rpm rpm-dev"
     PACKAGE_FEED_ARCHS = "all core2-64"

```

Given these settings, the resulting package feeds are as follows:

```
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm/core2-64
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm-dev/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm-dev/core2-64
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm/core2-64
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm-dev/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm-dev/core2-64

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_FEED_URIS[¶][2842]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the front portion of the package feed URI used by the OpenEmbedded build system. Each final package feed URI is comprised of `PACKAGE_FEED_URIS`, [`PACKAGE_FEED_BASE_PATHS`][2843], and[`PACKAGE_FEED_ARCHS`][2844] variables.

Consider the following example where the `PACKAGE_FEED_URIS`, `PACKAGE_FEED_BASE_PATHS`, and`PACKAGE_FEED_ARCHS` variables are defined in your `local.conf` file:

```
     PACKAGE_FEED_URIS = "https://example.com/packagerepos/release \
                          https://example.com/packagerepos/updates"
     PACKAGE_FEED_BASE_PATHS = "rpm rpm-dev"
     PACKAGE_FEED_ARCHS = "all core2-64"

```

Given these settings, the resulting package feeds are as follows:

```
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm/core2-64
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm-dev/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/release/rpm-dev/core2-64
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm/core2-64
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm-dev/all
     https://example.com/packagerepos/updates/rpm-dev/core2-64

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_GROUP[¶][2845]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The `PACKAGE_GROUP` variable has been renamed to [`FEATURE_PACKAGES`][2846]. See the variable description for `FEATURE_PACKAGES` for information.

If if you use the `PACKAGE_GROUP` variable, the OpenEmbedded build system issues a warning message.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_INSTALL[¶][2847]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The final list of packages passed to the package manager for installation into the image.

Because the package manager controls actual installation of all packages, the list of packages passed using `PACKAGE_INSTALL` is not the final list of packages that are actually installed. This variable is internal to the image construction code. Consequently, in general, you should use the[`IMAGE_INSTALL`][2848] variable to specify packages for installation. The exception to this is when working with the [`core-image-minimal-initramfs`][2849] image. When working with an initial RAM filesystem (initramfs) image, use the `PACKAGE_INSTALL` variable. For information on creating an initramfs, see the "[Building an Initial RAM Filesystem (initramfs) Image][2850]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_INSTALL_ATTEMPTONLY[¶][2851]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of packages the OpenEmbedded build system attempts to install when creating an image. If a listed package fails to install, the build system does not generate an error. This variable is generally not user-defined.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_PREPROCESS_FUNCS[¶][2852]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of functions run to pre-process the [`PKGD`][2853] directory prior to splitting the files out to individual packages.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGE_WRITE_DEPS[¶][2854]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of dependencies for post-installation and pre-installation scripts on native/cross tools. If your post-installation or pre-installation script can execute at rootfs creation time rather than on the target but depends on a native tool in order to execute, you need to list the tools in`PACKAGE_WRITE_DEPENDS`.

For information on running post-installation scripts, see the "[Post-Installation Scripts][2855]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGECONFIG[¶][2856]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

This variable provides a means of enabling or disabling features of a recipe on a per-recipe basis.`PACKAGECONFIG` blocks are defined in recipes when you specify features and then arguments that define feature behaviors. Here is the basic block structure:

```
     PACKAGECONFIG ??= "f1 f2 f3 ..."
     PACKAGECONFIG[f1] = "--with-f1,--without-f1,build-deps-f1,rt-deps-f1"
     PACKAGECONFIG[f2] = "--with-f2,--without-f2,build-deps-f2,rt-deps-f2"
     PACKAGECONFIG[f3] = "--with-f3,--without-f3,build-deps-f3,rt-deps-f3"

```

The `PACKAGECONFIG` variable itself specifies a space-separated list of the features to enable. Following the features, you can determine the behavior of each feature by providing up to four order-dependent arguments, which are separated by commas. You can omit any argument you like but must retain the separating commas. The order is important and specifies the following:

1.  Extra arguments that should be added to the configure script argument list ([`EXTRA_OECONF`][82] or[`PACKAGECONFIG_CONFARGS`][83]) if the feature is enabled.

2.  Extra arguments that should be added to `EXTRA_OECONF` or `PACKAGECONFIG_CONFARGS` if the feature is disabled.

3.  Additional build dependencies ([`DEPENDS`][84]) that should be added if the feature is enabled.

4.  Additional runtime dependencies ([`RDEPENDS`][85]) that should be added if the feature is enabled.

Consider the following `PACKAGECONFIG` block taken from the `librsvg` recipe. In this example the feature is `croco`, which has three arguments that determine the feature's behavior.

```
     PACKAGECONFIG ??= "croco"
     PACKAGECONFIG[croco] = "--with-croco,--without-croco,libcroco"

```

The `--with-croco` and `libcroco` arguments apply only if the feature is enabled. In this case, `--with-croco` is added to the configure script argument list and `libcroco` is added to `[DEPENDS][1519]`. On the other hand, if the feature is disabled say through a `.bbappend` file in another layer, then the second argument `--without-croco` is added to the configure script rather than `--with-croco`.

The basic `PACKAGECONFIG` structure previously described holds true regardless of whether you are creating a block or changing a block. When creating a block, use the structure inside your recipe.

If you want to change an existing `PACKAGECONFIG` block, you can do so one of two ways:

*   _Append file:_  Create an append file named  _`recipename`_ `.bbappend` in your layer and override the value of `PACKAGECONFIG`. You can either completely override the variable:

    ```
         PACKAGECONFIG="f4 f5"

    ```

    Or, you can just append the variable:

    ```
         PACKAGECONFIG_append = " f4"

    ```

*   _Configuration file:_  This method is identical to changing the block through an append file except you edit your `local.conf` or  `_`mydistro`_ .conf` file. As with append files previously described, you can either completely override the variable:

    ```
         PACKAGECONFIG_pn-recipename="f4 f5"

    ```

    Or, you can just amend the variable:

    ```
         PACKAGECONFIG_append_pn-recipename = " f4"

    ```

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">PACKAGECONFIG_CONFARGS[¶][2857]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A space-separated list of configuration options generated from the [`PACKAGECONFIG`][2858] setting.

Classes such as [`autotools`][2859] and [`cmake`][2860] use `PACKAGECONFIG_CONFARGS` to pass [`PACKAGECONFIG`][2861]options to `configure` and `cmake`, respectively.
