<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the `/usr/bin` subdirectory of the sysroot directory for the build host.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_DATADIR[¶][3144]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the `/usr/share` subdirectory of the sysroot directory for the target for which the current recipe is being built ([`STAGING_DIR_HOST`][3145]).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_DATADIR_NATIVE[¶][3146]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the `/usr/share` subdirectory of the sysroot directory for the build host.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_DIR[¶][3147]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the top-level sysroots directory (i.e. `${`[`TMPDIR`][3148]`}/sysroots`).

`STAGING_DIR` contains the directories that are staged into the sysroot by the [`do_populate_sysroot`][3149]task. See the [`SYSROOT_DIRS`][3150] variable and the "[Sharing Files Between Recipes][3151]" section for more information.

### Note

Recipes should never write files directly under the `STAGING_DIR` directory because the OpenEmbedded build system manages the directory automatically. Instead, files should be installed to `${`[`D`][3152]`}` within your recipe's [`do_install`][3153] task and then the OpenEmbedded build system will stage a subset of those files into the sysroot.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_DIR_HOST[¶][3154]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the sysroot directory for the system that the component is built to run on (the system that hosts the component). For most recipes, this sysroot is the one that the recipe's[`do_populate_sysroot`][3155] task copies files into. Exceptions include `-native` recipes, where the `do_populate_sysroot` task instead uses [`STAGING_DIR_NATIVE`][3156]. Depending on the type of recipe and the build target, `STAGING_DIR_HOST` can have the following values:

*   For recipes building for the target machine, the value is "${[STAGING_DIR][94]}/${[MACHINE][95]}".

*   For native recipes building for the build host, the value is empty given the assumption that when building for the build host, the build host's own directories should be used.

    ### Note

    `-native` recipes are not installed into host paths like such as `/usr`. Rather, these recipes are installed into `STAGING_DIR_NATIVE`. When compiling `-native` recipes, standard build environment variables such as [`CPPFLAGS`][4] and[`CFLAGS`][5] are set up so that both host paths and `STAGING_DIR_NATIVE` are searched for libraries and headers using, for example, GCC's `-isystem` option.

    This emphasizes that the `STAGING_DIR*` variables should be viewed as input variables by tasks such as [`do_configure`][6], [`do_compile`][7], and [`do_install`][8]. Having the real system root correspond to `STAGING_DIR_HOST` makes conceptual sense for `-native` recipes, as they make use of host headers and libraries.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_DIR_NATIVE[¶][3157]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the sysroot directory used when building components that run on the build host itself.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_DIR_TARGET[¶][3158]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the sysroot used for the system for which the component generates code. For components that do not generate code, which is the majority, `STAGING_DIR_TARGET` is set to match[`STAGING_DIR_HOST`][3159].

Some recipes build binaries that can run on the target system but those binaries in turn generate code for another different system (e.g. cross-canadian recipes). Using terminology from GNU, the primary system is referred to as the "HOST" and the secondary, or different, system is referred to as the "TARGET". Thus, the binaries run on the "HOST" system and generate binaries for the "TARGET" system. The `STAGING_DIR_HOST` variable points to the sysroot used for the "HOST" system, while`STAGING_DIR_TARGET` points to the sysroot used for the "TARGET" system.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_ETCDIR_NATIVE[¶][3160]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the `/etc` subdirectory of the sysroot directory for the build host.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_EXECPREFIXDIR[¶][3161]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the `/usr` subdirectory of the sysroot directory for the target for which the current recipe is being built ([`STAGING_DIR_HOST`][3162]).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_INCDIR[¶][3163]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the `/usr/include` subdirectory of the sysroot directory for the target for which the current recipe being built ([`STAGING_DIR_HOST`][3164]).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_INCDIR_NATIVE[¶][3165]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the `/usr/include` subdirectory of the sysroot directory for the build host.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_KERNEL_BUILDDIR[¶][3166]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Points to the directory containing the kernel build artifacts. Recipes building software that needs to access kernel build artifacts (e.g. `systemtap-uprobes`) can look in the directory specified with the`STAGING_KERNEL_BUILDDIR` variable to find these artifacts after the kernel has been built.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_KERNEL_DIR[¶][3167]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The directory with kernel headers that are required to build out-of-tree modules.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_LIBDIR[¶][3168]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the `/usr/lib` subdirectory of the sysroot directory for the target for which the current recipe is being built ([`STAGING_DIR_HOST`][3169]).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAGING_LIBDIR_NATIVE[¶][3170]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the path to the `/usr/lib` subdirectory of the sysroot directory for the build host.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAMP[¶][3171]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the base path used to create recipe stamp files. The path to an actual stamp file is constructed by evaluating this string and then appending additional information. Currently, the default assignment for `STAMP` as set in the `meta/conf/bitbake.conf` file is:

```
     STAMP = "${STAMPS_DIR}/${MULTIMACH_TARGET_SYS}/${PN}/${EXTENDPE}${PV}-${PR}"

```

For information on how BitBake uses stamp files to determine if a task should be rerun, see the "[Stamp Files and the Rerunning of Tasks][3172]" section.

See [`STAMPS_DIR`][3173], [`MULTIMACH_TARGET_SYS`][3174], [`PN`][3175], [`EXTENDPE`][3176], [`PV`][3177], and [`PR`][3178] for related variable information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STAMPS_DIR[¶][3179]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the base directory in which the OpenEmbedded build system places stamps. The default directory is `${TMPDIR}/stamps`.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">STRIP[¶][3180]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The minimal command and arguments to run `strip`, which is used to strip symbols.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SUMMARY[¶][3181]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The short (72 characters or less) summary of the binary package for packaging systems such as `opkg`, `rpm` or `dpkg`. By default, `SUMMARY` is used to define the [`DESCRIPTION`][3182] variable if `DESCRIPTION` is not set in the recipe.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SVNDIR[¶][3183]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The directory in which files checked out of a Subversion system are stored.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSLINUX_DEFAULT_CONSOLE[¶][3184]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the kernel boot default console. If you want to use a console other than the default, set this variable in your recipe as follows where "X" is the console number you want to use:

```
     SYSLINUX_DEFAULT_CONSOLE = "console=ttyX"

```

The [`syslinux`][3185] class initially sets this variable to null but then checks for a value later.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSLINUX_OPTS[¶][3186]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Lists additional options to add to the syslinux file. You need to set this variable in your recipe. If you want to list multiple options, separate the options with a semicolon character (`;`).

The [`syslinux`][3187] class uses this variable to create a set of options.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSLINUX_SERIAL[¶][3188]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the alternate serial port or turns it off. To turn off serial, set this variable to an empty string in your recipe. The variable's default value is set in the [`syslinux`][3189] as follows:

```
     SYSLINUX_SERIAL ?= "0 115200"

```

The class checks for and uses the variable as needed.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSLINUX_SPLASH[¶][3190]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

An `.LSS` file used as the background for the VGA boot menu when you are using the boot menu. You need to set this variable in your recipe.

The [`syslinux`][3191] class checks for this variable and if found, the OpenEmbedded build system installs the splash screen.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSLINUX_SERIAL_TTY[¶][3192]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the alternate console=tty... kernel boot argument. The variable's default value is set in the[`syslinux`][3193] as follows:

```
     SYSLINUX_SERIAL_TTY ?= "console=ttyS0,115200"

```

The class checks for and uses the variable as needed.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSROOT_DIRS[¶][3194]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Directories that are staged into the sysroot by the [`do_populate_sysroot`][3195] task. By default, the following directories are staged:

```
     SYSROOT_DIRS = " \
         ${includedir} \
         ${libdir} \
         ${base_libdir} \
         ${nonarch_base_libdir} \
         ${datadir} \
     "

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSROOT_DIRS_BLACKLIST[¶][3196]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Directories that are not staged into the sysroot by the [`do_populate_sysroot`][3197] task. You can use this variable to exclude certain subdirectories of directories listed in [`SYSROOT_DIRS`][3198] from staging. By default, the following directories are not staged:

```
     SYSROOT_DIRS_BLACKLIST = " \
         ${mandir} \
         ${docdir} \
         ${infodir} \
         ${datadir}/locale \
         ${datadir}/applications \
         ${datadir}/fonts \
         ${datadir}/pixmaps \
     "

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSROOT_DIRS_NATIVE[¶][3199]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Extra directories staged into the sysroot by the [`do_populate_sysroot`][3200] task for `-native` recipes, in addition to those specified in [`SYSROOT_DIRS`][3201]. By default, the following extra directories are staged:

```
     SYSROOT_DIRS_NATIVE = " \
         ${bindir} \
         ${sbindir} \
         ${base_bindir} \
         ${base_sbindir} \
         ${libexecdir} \
         ${sysconfdir} \
         ${localstatedir} \
     "

```

### Note

Programs built by `-native` recipes run directly from the sysroot ([`STAGING_DIR_NATIVE`][3202]), which is why additional directories containing program executables and supporting files need to be staged.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSROOT_PREPROCESS_FUNCS[¶][3203]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of functions to execute after files are staged into the sysroot. These functions are usually used to apply additional processing on the staged files, or to stage additional files.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSTEMD_AUTO_ENABLE[¶][3204]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`systemd`][3205] class, this variable specifies whether the service you have specified in[`SYSTEMD_SERVICE`][3206] should be started automatically or not. By default, the service is enabled to automatically start at boot time. The default setting is in the [`systemd`][3207] class as follows:

```
     SYSTEMD_AUTO_ENABLE ??= "enable"

```

You can disable the service by setting the variable to "disable".

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSTEMD_BOOT_CFG[¶][3208]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When [`EFI_PROVIDER`][3209] is set to "systemd-boot", the `SYSTEMD_BOOT_CFG` variable specifies the configuration file that should be used. By default, the [`systemd-boot`][3210] class sets the `SYSTEMD_BOOT_CFG` as follows:

```
     SYSTEMD_BOOT_CFG ?= "${S}/loader.conf"

```

For information on Systemd-boot, see the [Systemd-boot documentation][3212].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSTEMD_BOOT_ENTRIES[¶][3213]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When [`EFI_PROVIDER`][3214] is set to "systemd-boot", the `SYSTEMD_BOOT_ENTRIES` variable specifies a list of entry files (`*.conf`) to be installed containing one boot entry per file. By default, the [`systemd-boot`][3215]class sets the `SYSTEMD_BOOT_ENTRIES` as follows:

```
     SYSTEMD_BOOT_ENTRIES ?= ""

```

For information on Systemd-boot, see the [Systemd-boot documentation][3216].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSTEMD_BOOT_TIMEOUT[¶][3217]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When [`EFI_PROVIDER`][3218] is set to "systemd-boot", the `SYSTEMD_BOOT_TIMEOUT` variable specifies the boot menu timeout in seconds. By default, the [`systemd-boot`][3219] class sets the `SYSTEMD_BOOT_TIMEOUT`as follows:

```
     SYSTEMD_BOOT_TIMEOUT ?= "10"

```

For information on Systemd-boot, see the [Systemd-boot documentation][3220].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSTEMD_PACKAGES[¶][3221]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`systemd`][3222] class, this variable locates the systemd unit files when they are not found in the main recipe's package. By default, the `SYSTEMD_PACKAGES` variable is set such that the systemd unit files are assumed to reside in the recipes main package:

```
     SYSTEMD_PACKAGES ?= "${PN}"

```

If these unit files are not in this recipe's main package, you need to use `SYSTEMD_PACKAGES` to list the package or packages in which the build system can find the systemd unit files.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSTEMD_SERVICE[¶][3223]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`systemd`][3224] class, this variable specifies the systemd service name for a package.

When you specify this file in your recipe, use a package name override to indicate the package to which the value applies. Here is an example from the connman recipe:

```
     SYSTEMD_SERVICE_${PN} = "connman.service"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">SYSVINIT_ENABLED_GETTYS[¶][3225]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When using [SysVinit][3226], specifies a space-separated list of the virtual terminals that should be running a [getty][3227] (allowing login), assuming [`USE_VT`][3228] is not set to "0".

The default value for `SYSVINIT_ENABLED_GETTYS` is "1" (i.e. only run a getty on the first virtual terminal).

</dd>

</dl>

### T

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">T[¶][3229]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

This variable points to a directory were BitBake places temporary files, which consist mostly of task logs and scripts, when building a particular recipe. The variable is typically set as follows:

```
     T = "${WORKDIR}/temp"

```

The [`WORKDIR`][3230] is the directory into which BitBake unpacks and builds the recipe. The default `bitbake.conf` file sets this variable.

The `T` variable is not to be confused with the [`TMPDIR`][3231] variable, which points to the root of the directory tree where BitBake places the output of an entire build.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_ARCH[¶][3232]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The target machine's architecture. The OpenEmbedded build system supports many architectures. Here is an example list of architectures supported. This list is by no means complete as the architecture is configurable:

```
     arm
     i586
     x86_64
     powerpc
     powerpc64
     mips
     mipsel

```

For additional information on machine architectures, see the [`TUNE_ARCH`][3233] variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_AS_ARCH[¶][3234]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies architecture-specific assembler flags for the target system. `TARGET_AS_ARCH` is initialized from [`TUNE_ASARGS`][3235] by default in the BitBake configuration file (`meta/conf/bitbake.conf`):

```
     TARGET_AS_ARCH = "${TUNE_ASARGS}"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_CC_ARCH[¶][3236]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies architecture-specific C compiler flags for the target system. `TARGET_CC_ARCH` is initialized from [`TUNE_CCARGS`][3237] by default.

### Note

It is a common workaround to append [`LDFLAGS`][3238] to `TARGET_CC_ARCH` in recipes that build software for the target that would not otherwise respect the exported`LDFLAGS` variable.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_CC_KERNEL_ARCH[¶][3239]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

This is a specific kernel compiler flag for a CPU or Application Binary Interface (ABI) tune. The flag is used rarely and only for cases where a userspace [`TUNE_CCARGS`][3240] is not compatible with the kernel compilation. The `TARGET_CC_KERNEL_ARCH` variable allows the kernel (and associated modules) to use a different configuration. See the `meta/conf/machine/include/arm/feature-arm-thumb.inc`file in the [Source Directory][3241] for an example.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_CFLAGS[¶][3242]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the flags to pass to the C compiler when building for the target. When building in the target context, [`CFLAGS`][3243] is set to the value of this variable by default.

Additionally, the SDK's environment setup script sets the [`CFLAGS`][3244] variable in the environment to the`TARGET_CFLAGS` value so that executables built using the SDK also have the flags applied.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_CPPFLAGS[¶][3245]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the flags to pass to the C pre-processor (i.e. to both the C and the C++ compilers) when building for the target. When building in the target context, [`CPPFLAGS`][3246] is set to the value of this variable by default.

Additionally, the SDK's environment setup script sets the [`CPPFLAGS`][3247] variable in the environment to the `TARGET_CPPFLAGS` value so that executables built using the SDK also have the flags applied.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_CXXFLAGS[¶][3248]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the flags to pass to the C++ compiler when building for the target. When building in the target context, [`CXXFLAGS`][3249] is set to the value of this variable by default.

Additionally, the SDK's environment setup script sets the [`CXXFLAGS`][3250] variable in the environment to the `TARGET_CXXFLAGS` value so that executables built using the SDK also have the flags applied.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_FPU[¶][3251]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the method for handling FPU code. For FPU-less targets, which include most ARM CPUs, the variable must be set to "soft". If not, the kernel emulation gets used, which results in a performance penalty.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_LD_ARCH[¶][3252]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies architecture-specific linker flags for the target system. `TARGET_LD_ARCH` is initialized from[`TUNE_LDARGS`][3253] by default in the BitBake configuration file (`meta/conf/bitbake.conf`):

```
     TARGET_LD_ARCH = "${TUNE_LDARGS}"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_LDFLAGS[¶][3254]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the flags to pass to the linker when building for the target. When building in the target context, [`LDFLAGS`][3255] is set to the value of this variable by default.

Additionally, the SDK's environment setup script sets the [`LDFLAGS`][3256] variable in the environment to the`TARGET_LDFLAGS` value so that executables built using the SDK also have the flags applied.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_OS[¶][3257]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the target's operating system. The variable can be set to "linux" for `glibc`-based systems and to "linux-uclibc" for `uclibc`. For ARM/EABI targets, there are also "linux-gnueabi" and "linux-uclibc-gnueabi" values possible.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_PREFIX[¶][3258]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the prefix used for the toolchain binary target tools.

Depending on the type of recipe and the build target, `TARGET_PREFIX` is set as follows:

*   For recipes building for the target machine, the value is "${[TARGET_SYS][96]}-".

*   For native recipes, the build system sets the variable to the value of `BUILD_PREFIX`.

*   For native SDK recipes (`nativesdk`), the build system sets the variable to the value of`SDK_PREFIX`.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_SYS[¶][3259]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the system, including the architecture and the operating system, for which the build is occurring in the context of the current recipe.

The OpenEmbedded build system automatically sets this variable based on [`TARGET_ARCH`][3260],[`TARGET_VENDOR`][3261], and [`TARGET_OS`][3262] variables.

### Note

You do not need to set the `TARGET_SYS` variable yourself.

Consider these two examples:

*   Given a native recipe on a 32-bit, x86 machine running Linux, the value is "i686-linux".

*   Given a recipe being built for a little-endian, MIPS target running Linux, the value might be "mipsel-linux".

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TARGET_VENDOR[¶][3263]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the name of the target vendor.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TCLIBCAPPEND[¶][3264]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a suffix to be appended onto the [`TMPDIR`][3265] value. The suffix identifies the `libc` variant for building. When you are building for multiple variants with the same [Build Directory][3266], this mechanism ensures that output for different `libc` variants is kept separate to avoid potential conflicts.

In the `defaultsetup.conf` file, the default value of `TCLIBCAPPEND` is "-${TCLIBC}". However, distros such as poky, which normally only support one `libc` variant, set `TCLIBCAPPEND` to "" in their distro configuration file resulting in no suffix being applied.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TCLIBC[¶][3267]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the GNU standard C library (`libc`) variant to use during the build process. This variable replaces `POKYLIBC`, which is no longer supported.

You can select "glibc" or "uclibc".

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TCMODE[¶][3268]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the toolchain selector. `TCMODE` controls the characteristics of the generated packages and images by telling the OpenEmbedded build system which toolchain profile to use. By default, the OpenEmbedded build system builds its own internal toolchain. The variable's default value is "default", which uses that internal toolchain.

### Note

If `TCMODE` is set to a value other than "default", then it is your responsibility to ensure that the toolchain is compatible with the default toolchain. Using older or newer versions of these components might cause build problems. See the [Release Notes][3269] for the specific components with which the toolchain must be compatible.

The `TCMODE` variable is similar to [`TCLIBC`][3270], which controls the variant of the GNU standard C library (`libc`) used during the build process: `glibc` or `uclibc`.

With additional layers, it is possible to use a pre-compiled external toolchain. One example is the Sourcery G++ Toolchain. The support for this toolchain resides in the separate Mentor Graphics®`meta-sourcery` layer at [http://github.com/MentorEmbedded/meta-sourcery/][3271].

The layer's `README` file contains information on how to use the Sourcery G++ Toolchain as an external toolchain. In summary, you must be sure to add the layer to your `bblayers.conf` file in front of the `meta` layer and then set the `EXTERNAL_TOOLCHAIN` variable in your `local.conf` file to the location in which you installed the toolchain.

The fundamentals used for this example apply to any external toolchain. You can use `meta-sourcery` as a template for adding support for other external toolchains.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_EXPORT_DIR[¶][3272]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The location the OpenEmbedded build system uses to export tests when the [`TEST_EXPORT_ONLY`][3273]variable is set to "1".

The `TEST_EXPORT_DIR` variable defaults to `"${TMPDIR}/testimage/${PN}"`.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_EXPORT_ONLY[¶][3274]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies to export the tests only. Set this variable to "1" if you do not want to run the tests but you want them to be exported in a manner that you to run them outside of the build system.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_IMAGE[¶][3275]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Automatically runs the series of automated tests for images when an image is successfully built.

These tests are written in Python making use of the `unittest` module, and the majority of them run commands on the target system over `ssh`. You can set this variable to "1" in your `local.conf` file in the [Build Directory][3276] to have the OpenEmbedded build system automatically run these tests after an image successfully builds:

```
     TEST_IMAGE = "1"

```

For more information on enabling, running, and writing these tests, see the "[Performing Automated Runtime Testing][3277]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual and the "[`testimage*.bbclass`][3278]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_LOG_DIR[¶][3279]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Holds the SSH log and the boot log for QEMU machines. The `TEST_LOG_DIR` variable defaults to `"${WORKDIR}/testimage"`.

### Note

Actual test results reside in the task log (`log.do_testimage`), which is in the `${WORKDIR}/temp/` directory.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_POWERCONTROL_CMD[¶][3280]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

For automated hardware testing, specifies the command to use to control the power of the target machine under test. Typically, this command would point to a script that performs the appropriate action (e.g. interacting with a web-enabled power strip). The specified command should expect to receive as the last argument "off", "on" or "cycle" specifying to power off, on, or cycle (power off and then power on) the device, respectively.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_POWERCONTROL_EXTRA_ARGS[¶][3281]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

For automated hardware testing, specifies additional arguments to pass through to the command specified in [`TEST_POWERCONTROL_CMD`][3282]. Setting `TEST_POWERCONTROL_EXTRA_ARGS` is optional. You can use it if you wish, for example, to separate the machine-specific and non-machine-specific parts of the arguments.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_QEMUBOOT_TIMEOUT[¶][3283]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The time in seconds allowed for an image to boot before automated runtime tests begin to run against an image. The default timeout period to allow the boot process to reach the login prompt is 500 seconds. You can specify a different value in the `local.conf` file.

For more information on testing images, see the "[Performing Automated Runtime Testing][3284]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_SERIALCONTROL_CMD[¶][3285]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

For automated hardware testing, specifies the command to use to connect to the serial console of the target machine under test. This command simply needs to connect to the serial console and forward that connection to standard input and output as any normal terminal program does.

For example, to use the Picocom terminal program on serial device `/dev/ttyUSB0` at 115200bps, you would set the variable as follows:

```
     TEST_SERIALCONTROL_CMD = "picocom /dev/ttyUSB0 -b 115200"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_SERIALCONTROL_EXTRA_ARGS[¶][3286]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

For automated hardware testing, specifies additional arguments to pass through to the command specified in [`TEST_SERIALCONTROL_CMD`][3287]. Setting `TEST_SERIALCONTROL_EXTRA_ARGS` is optional. You can use it if you wish, for example, to separate the machine-specific and non-machine-specific parts of the command.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_SERVER_IP[¶][3288]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The IP address of the build machine (host machine). This IP address is usually automatically detected. However, if detection fails, this variable needs to be set to the IP address of the build machine (i.e. where the build is taking place).

### Note

The `TEST_SERVER_IP` variable is only used for a small number of tests such as the "dnf" test suite, which needs to download packages from `WORKDIR/oe-rootfs-repo`.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_TARGET[¶][3289]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the target controller to use when running tests against a test image. The default controller to use is "qemu":

```
     TEST_TARGET = "qemu"

```

A target controller is a class that defines how an image gets deployed on a target and how a target is started. A layer can extend the controllers by adding a module in the layer's `/lib/oeqa/controllers` directory and by inheriting the `BaseTarget` class, which is an abstract class that cannot be used as a value of `TEST_TARGET`.

You can provide the following arguments with `TEST_TARGET`:

*   _"qemu" and "QemuTarget":_  Boots a QEMU image and runs the tests. See the "[Enabling Runtime Tests on QEMU][97]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual for more information.

*   _"simpleremote" and "SimpleRemoteTarget":_  Runs the tests on target hardware that is already up and running. The hardware can be on the network or it can be a device running an image on QEMU. You must also set [`TEST_TARGET_IP`][98] when you use "simpleremote" or "SimpleRemoteTarget".

    ### Note

    This argument is defined in `meta/lib/oeqa/targetcontrol.py`. The small caps names are kept for compatibility reasons.

*   _"GummibootTarget":_  Automatically deploys and runs tests on an EFI-enabled machine that has a master image installed.

    ### Note

    This argument is defined in `meta/lib/oeqa/controllers/masterimage.py`.

For information on running tests on hardware, see the "[Enabling Runtime Tests on Hardware][3290]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_TARGET_IP[¶][3291]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The IP address of your hardware under test. The `TEST_TARGET_IP` variable has no effect when[`TEST_TARGET`][3292] is set to "qemu".

When you specify the IP address, you can also include a port. Here is an example:

```
     TEST_TARGET_IP = "192.168.1.4:2201"

```

Specifying a port is useful when SSH is started on a non-standard port or in cases when your hardware under test is behind a firewall or network that is not directly accessible from your host and you need to do port address translation.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TEST_SUITES[¶][3293]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

An ordered list of tests (modules) to run against an image when performing automated runtime testing.

The OpenEmbedded build system provides a core set of tests that can be used against images.

### Note

Currently, there is only support for running these tests under QEMU.

Tests include `ping`, `ssh`, `df` among others. You can add your own tests to the list of tests by appending `TEST_SUITES` as follows:

```
     TEST_SUITES_append = " mytest"

```

Alternatively, you can provide the "auto" option to have all applicable tests run against the image.

```
     TEST_SUITES_append = " auto"

```

Using this option causes the build system to automatically run tests that are applicable to the image. Tests that are not applicable are skipped.

The order in which tests are run is important. Tests that depend on another test must appear later in the list than the test on which they depend. For example, if you append the list of tests with two tests (`test_A` and `test_B`) where `test_B` is dependent on `test_A`, then you must order the tests as follows:

```
     TEST_SUITES = " test_A test_B"

```

For more information on testing images, see the "[Performing Automated Runtime Testing][3294]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">THISDIR[¶][3295]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The directory in which the file BitBake is currently parsing is located. Do not manually set this variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TIME[¶][3296]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The time the build was started. Times appear using the hour, minute, and second (HMS) format (e.g. "140159" for one minute and fifty-nine seconds past 1400 hours).

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TMPDIR[¶][3297]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

This variable is the base directory the OpenEmbedded build system uses for all build output and intermediate files (other than the shared state cache). By default, the `TMPDIR` variable points to `tmp`within the [Build Directory][3298].

If you want to establish this directory in a location other than the default, you can uncomment and edit the following statement in the `conf/local.conf` file in the [Source Directory][3299]:

```
     #TMPDIR = "${TOPDIR}/tmp"

```

An example use for this scenario is to set `TMPDIR` to a local disk, which does not use NFS, while having the Build Directory use NFS.

The filesystem used by `TMPDIR` must have standard filesystem semantics (i.e. mixed-case files are unique, POSIX file locking, and persistent inodes). Due to various issues with NFS and bugs in some implementations, NFS does not meet this minimum requirement. Consequently, `TMPDIR` cannot be on NFS.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TOOLCHAIN_HOST_TASK[¶][3300]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

This variable lists packages the OpenEmbedded build system uses when building an SDK, which contains a cross-development environment. The packages specified by this variable are part of the toolchain set that runs on the [`SDKMACHINE`][3301], and each package should usually have the prefix`nativesdk-`. For example, consider the following command when building an SDK:

```
     $ bitbake -c populate_sdk imagename

```

In this case, a default list of packages is set in this variable, but you can add additional packages to the list. See the "[Adding Individual Packages to the Standard SDK][3302]" section in the Yocto Project Software Development Kit (SDK) Developer's Guide for more information.

For background information on cross-development toolchains in the Yocto Project development environment, see the "[Cross-Development Toolchain Generation][3303]" section. For information on setting up a cross-development environment, see the [Yocto Project Software Development Kit (SDK) Developer's Guide][3304].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TOOLCHAIN_OUTPUTNAME[¶][3305]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

This variable defines the name used for the toolchain output. The [`populate_sdk_base`][3306] class sets the`TOOLCHAIN_OUTPUTNAME` variable as follows:

```
     TOOLCHAIN_OUTPUTNAME ?= "${SDK_NAME}-toolchain-${SDK_VERSION}"

```

See the [`SDK_NAME`][3307] and [`SDK_VERSION`][3308] variables for additional information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TOOLCHAIN_TARGET_TASK[¶][3309]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

This variable lists packages the OpenEmbedded build system uses when it creates the target part of an SDK (i.e. the part built for the target hardware), which includes libraries and headers. Use this variable to add individual packages to the part of the SDK that runs on the target. See the "[Adding Individual Packages to the Standard SDK][3310]" section in the Yocto Project Software Development Kit (SDK) Developer's Guide for more information.

For background information on cross-development toolchains in the Yocto Project development environment, see the "[Cross-Development Toolchain Generation][3311]" section. For information on setting up a cross-development environment, see the [Yocto Project Software Development Kit (SDK) Developer's Guide][3312].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TOPDIR[¶][3313]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The top-level [Build Directory][3314]. BitBake automatically sets this variable when you initialize your build environment using either [`oe-init-build-env`][3315] or [`oe-init-build-env-memres`][3316].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TRANSLATED_TARGET_ARCH[¶][3317]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A sanitized version of [`TARGET_ARCH`][3318]. This variable is used where the architecture is needed in a value where underscores are not allowed, for example within package filenames. In this case, dash characters replace any underscore characters used in TARGET_ARCH.

Do not edit this variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNE_ARCH[¶][3319]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The GNU canonical architecture for a specific architecture (i.e. `arm`, `armeb`, `mips`, `mips64`, and so forth). BitBake uses this value to setup configuration.

`TUNE_ARCH` definitions are specific to a given architecture. The definitions can be a single static definition, or can be dynamically adjusted. You can see details for a given CPU family by looking at the architecture's `README` file. For example, the `meta/conf/machine/include/mips/README` file in the [Source Directory][3320] provides information for `TUNE_ARCH` specific to the `mips` architecture.

`TUNE_ARCH` is tied closely to [`TARGET_ARCH`][3321], which defines the target machine's architecture. The BitBake configuration file (`meta/conf/bitbake.conf`) sets `TARGET_ARCH` as follows:

```
     TARGET_ARCH = "${TUNE_ARCH}"

```

The following list, which is by no means complete since architectures are configurable, shows supported machine architectures:

```
     arm
     i586
     x86_64
     powerpc
     powerpc64
     mips
     mipsel

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNE_ASARGS[¶][3322]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies architecture-specific assembler flags for the target system. The set of flags is based on the selected tune features. `TUNE_ASARGS` is set using the tune include files, which are typically under`meta/conf/machine/include/` and are influenced through [`TUNE_FEATURES`][3323]. For example, the`meta/conf/machine/include/x86/arch-x86.inc` file defines the flags for the x86 architecture as follows:

```
     TUNE_ASARGS += "${@bb.utils.contains("TUNE_FEATURES", "mx32", "-x32", "", d)}"

```

### Note

Board Support Packages (BSPs) select the tune. The selected tune, in turn, affects the tune variables themselves (i.e. the tune can supply its own set of flags).</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNE_CCARGS[¶][3324]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies architecture-specific C compiler flags for the target system. The set of flags is based on the selected tune features. `TUNE_CCARGS` is set using the tune include files, which are typically under`meta/conf/machine/include/` and are influenced through [`TUNE_FEATURES`][3325].

### Note

Board Support Packages (BSPs) select the tune. The selected tune, in turn, affects the tune variables themselves (i.e. the tune can supply its own set of flags).</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNE_LDARGS[¶][3326]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies architecture-specific linker flags for the target system. The set of flags is based on the selected tune features. `TUNE_LDARGS` is set using the tune include files, which are typically under`meta/conf/machine/include/` and are influenced through [`TUNE_FEATURES`][3327]. For example, the`meta/conf/machine/include/x86/arch-x86.inc` file defines the flags for the x86 architecture as follows:

```
     TUNE_LDARGS += "${@bb.utils.contains("TUNE_FEATURES", "mx32", "-m elf32_x86_64", "", d)}"

```

### Note

Board Support Packages (BSPs) select the tune. The selected tune, in turn, affects the tune variables themselves (i.e. the tune can supply its own set of flags).</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNE_FEATURES[¶][3328]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Features used to "tune" a compiler for optimal use given a specific processor. The features are defined within the tune files and allow arguments (i.e. `TUNE_*ARGS`) to be dynamically generated based on the features.

The OpenEmbedded build system verifies the features to be sure they are not conflicting and that they are supported.

The BitBake configuration file (`meta/conf/bitbake.conf`) defines `TUNE_FEATURES` as follows:

```
     TUNE_FEATURES ??= "${TUNE_FEATURES_tune-${DEFAULTTUNE}}"

```

See the [`DEFAULTTUNE`][3329] variable for more information.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNE_PKGARCH[¶][3330]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The package architecture understood by the packaging system to define the architecture, ABI, and tuning of output packages. The specific tune is defined using the "_tune" override as follows:

```
     TUNE_PKGARCH_tune-tune = "tune"

```

These tune-specific package architectures are defined in the machine include files. Here is an example of the "core2-32" tuning as used in the `meta/conf/machine/include/tune-core2.inc` file:

```
     TUNE_PKGARCH_tune-core2-32 = "core2-32"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNEABI[¶][3331]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

An underlying Application Binary Interface (ABI) used by a particular tuning in a given toolchain layer. Providers that use prebuilt libraries can use the `TUNEABI`, [`TUNEABI_OVERRIDE`][3332], and[`TUNEABI_WHITELIST`][3333] variables to check compatibility of tunings against their selection of libraries.

If `TUNEABI` is undefined, then every tuning is allowed. See the [`sanity`][3334] class to see how the variable is used.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNEABI_OVERRIDE[¶][3335]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

If set, the OpenEmbedded system ignores the [`TUNEABI_WHITELIST`][3336] variable. Providers that use prebuilt libraries can use the `TUNEABI_OVERRIDE`, `TUNEABI_WHITELIST`, and [`TUNEABI`][3337] variables to check compatibility of a tuning against their selection of libraries.

See the [`sanity`][3338] class to see how the variable is used.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNEABI_WHITELIST[¶][3339]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A whitelist of permissible [`TUNEABI`][3340] values. If `TUNEABI_WHITELIST` is not set, all tunes are allowed. Providers that use prebuilt libraries can use the `TUNEABI_WHITELIST`, [`TUNEABI_OVERRIDE`][3341], and `TUNEABI` variables to check compatibility of a tuning against their selection of libraries.

See the [`sanity`][3342] class to see how the variable is used.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNECONFLICTS[ _`feature`_ ][¶][3343]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies CPU or Application Binary Interface (ABI) tuning features that conflict with  _`feature`_ .

Known tuning conflicts are specified in the machine include files in the [Source Directory][3344]. Here is an example from the `meta/conf/machine/include/mips/arch-mips.inc` include file that lists the "o32" and "n64" features as conflicting with the "n32" feature:

```
     TUNECONFLICTS[n32] = "o32 n64"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">TUNEVALID[ _`feature`_ ][¶][3345]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a valid CPU or Application Binary Interface (ABI) tuning feature. The specified feature is stored as a flag. Valid features are specified in the machine include files (e.g. `meta/conf/machine/include/arm/arch-arm.inc`). Here is an example from that file:

```
     TUNEVALID[bigendian] = "Enable big-endian mode."

```

See the machine include files in the [Source Directory][3346] for these features.

</dd>

</dl>

### U

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UBOOT_CONFIG[¶][3347]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Configures the [`UBOOT_MACHINE`][3348] and can also define [`IMAGE_FSTYPES`][3349] for individual cases.

Following is an example from the `meta-fsl-arm` layer.

```
     UBOOT_CONFIG ??= "sd"
     UBOOT_CONFIG[sd] = "mx6qsabreauto_config,sdcard"
     UBOOT_CONFIG[eimnor] = "mx6qsabreauto_eimnor_config"
     UBOOT_CONFIG[nand] = "mx6qsabreauto_nand_config,ubifs"
     UBOOT_CONFIG[spinor] = "mx6qsabreauto_spinor_config"

```

In this example, "sd" is selected as the configuration of the possible four for the `UBOOT_MACHINE`. The "sd" configuration defines "mx6qsabreauto_config" as the value for `UBOOT_MACHINE`, while the "sdcard" specifies the `IMAGE_FSTYPES` to use for the U-boot image.

For more information on how the `UBOOT_CONFIG` is handled, see the [`uboot-config`][3350] class.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UBOOT_ENTRYPOINT[¶][3351]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the entry point for the U-Boot image. During U-Boot image creation, the`UBOOT_ENTRYPOINT` variable is passed as a command-line parameter to the `uboot-mkimage` utility.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UBOOT_LOADADDRESS[¶][3352]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the load address for the U-Boot image. During U-Boot image creation, the`UBOOT_LOADADDRESS` variable is passed as a command-line parameter to the `uboot-mkimage` utility.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UBOOT_LOCALVERSION[¶][3353]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Appends a string to the name of the local version of the U-Boot image. For example, assuming the version of the U-Boot image built was "2013.10, the full version string reported by U-Boot would be "2013.10-yocto" given the following statement:

```
     UBOOT_LOCALVERSION = "-yocto"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UBOOT_MACHINE[¶][3354]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the value passed on the `make` command line when building a U-Boot image. The value indicates the target platform configuration. You typically set this variable from the machine configuration file (i.e. `conf/machine/ _`machine_name`_ .conf`).

Please see the "Selection of Processor Architecture and Board Type" section in the U-Boot README for valid values for this variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UBOOT_MAKE_TARGET[¶][3355]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the target called in the `Makefile`. The default target is "all".

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UBOOT_SUFFIX[¶][3356]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Points to the generated U-Boot extension. For example, `u-boot.sb` has a `.sb` extension.

The default U-Boot extension is `.bin`

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UBOOT_TARGET[¶][3357]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the target used for building U-Boot. The target is passed directly as part of the "make" command (e.g. SPL and AIS). If you do not specifically set this variable, the OpenEmbedded build process passes and uses "all" for the target during the U-Boot building process.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UNKNOWN_CONFIGURE_WHITELIST[¶][3358]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a list of options that, if reported by the configure script as being invalid, should not generate a warning during the [`do_configure`][3359] task. Normally, invalid configure options are simply not passed to the configure script (e.g. should be removed from [`EXTRA_OECONF`][3360] or[`PACKAGECONFIG_CONFARGS`][3361]). However, common options, for example, exist that are passed to all configure scripts at a class level that might not be valid for some configure scripts. It follows that no benefit exists in seeing a warning about these options. For these cases, the options are added to`UNKNOWN_CONFIGURE_WHITELIST`.

The configure arguments check that uses `UNKNOWN_CONFIGURE_WHITELIST` is part of the [`insane`][3362]class and is only enabled if the recipe inherits the [`autotools`][3363] class.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UPDATERCPN[¶][3364]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

For recipes inheriting the [`update-rc.d`][3365] class, `UPDATERCPN` specifies the package that contains the initscript that is to be enabled.

The default value is "${PN}". Given that almost all recipes that install initscripts package them in the main package for the recipe, you rarely need to set this variable in individual recipes.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UPSTREAM_CHECK_GITTAGREGEX[¶][3366]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When the [`distrodata`][3367] class is enabled globally, you can perform a per-recipe check for what the latest upstream source code version is by calling `bitbake -c checkpkg`  _`recipe`_ . If the recipe source code is provided from Git repositories, the OpenEmbedded build system determines the latest upstream version by picking the latest tag from the list of all repository tags. You can use the`UPSTREAM_CHECK_GITTAGREGEX` variable to provide a regular expression to filter only the relevant tags should the default filter not work correctly.

```
     UPSTREAM_CHECK_GITTAGREGEX = "git_tag_regex"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UPSTREAM_CHECK_REGEX[¶][3368]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When the [`distrodata`][3369] class is enabled globally, use the `UPSTREAM_CHECK_REGEX` variable to specify a different regular expression instead of the default one when the package checking system is parsing the page found using [`UPSTREAM_CHECK_URI`][3370].

```
     UPSTREAM_CHECK_REGEX = "package_regex"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">UPSTREAM_CHECK_URI[¶][3371]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When the [`distrodata`][3372] class is enabled globally, you can perform a per-recipe check for what the latest upstream source code version is by calling `bitbake -c checkpkg`  _`recipe`_ . If the source code is provided from tarballs, the latest version is determined by fetching the directory listing where the tarball is and attempting to find a later tarball. When this approach does not work, you can use`UPSTREAM_CHECK_URI` to provide a different URI that contains the link to the latest tarball.

```
     UPSTREAM_CHECK_URI = "recipe_url"

```
</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">USE_DEVFS[¶][3373]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Determines if `devtmpfs` is used for `/dev` population. The default value used for `USE_DEVFS` is "1" when no value is specifically set. Typically, you would set `USE_DEVFS` to "0" for a statically populated `/dev` directory.

See the "[Selecting a Device Manager][3374]" section in the Yocto Project Development Manual for information on how to use this variable.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">USE_VT[¶][3375]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When using [SysVinit][3376], determines whether or not to run a [getty][3377] on any virtual terminals in order to enable logging in through those terminals.

The default value used for `USE_VT` is "1" when no default value is specifically set. Typically, you would set `USE_VT` to "0" in the machine configuration file for machines that do not have a graphical display attached and therefore do not need virtual terminal functionality.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">USER_CLASSES[¶][3378]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

A list of classes to globally inherit. These classes are used by the OpenEmbedded build system to enable extra features (e.g. `buildstats`, `image-mklibs`, and so forth).

The default list is set in your `local.conf` file:

```
     USER_CLASSES ?= "buildstats image-mklibs image-prelink"

```

For more information, see `meta-poky/conf/local.conf.sample` in the [Source Directory][3379].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">USERADD_ERROR_DYNAMIC[¶][3380]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

If set to "error", forces the OpenEmbedded build system to produce an error if the user identification (`uid`) and group identification (`gid`) values are not defined in `files/passwd` and `files/group` files. If set to "warn", a warning will be issued instead.

The default behavior for the build system is to dynamically apply `uid` and `gid` values. Consequently, the `USERADD_ERROR_DYNAMIC` variable is by default not set. If you plan on using statically assigned`gid` and `uid` values, you should set the `USERADD_ERROR_DYNAMIC` variable in your `local.conf` file as follows:

```
     USERADD_ERROR_DYNAMIC = "error"

```

Overriding the default behavior implies you are going to also take steps to set static `uid` and `gid`values through use of the [`USERADDEXTENSION`][3381], [`USERADD_UID_TABLES`][3382], and [`USERADD_GID_TABLES`][3383]variables.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">USERADD_GID_TABLES[¶][3384]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a password file to use for obtaining static group identification (`gid`) values when the OpenEmbedded build system adds a group to the system during package installation.

When applying static group identification (`gid`) values, the OpenEmbedded build system looks in[`BBPATH`][3385] for a `files/group` file and then applies those `uid` values. Set the variable as follows in your`local.conf` file:

```
     USERADD_GID_TABLES = "files/group"

```

### Note

Setting the [`USERADDEXTENSION`][3386] variable to "useradd-staticids" causes the build system to use static `gid` values.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">USERADD_PACKAGES[¶][3387]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`useradd`][3388] class, this variable specifies the individual packages within the recipe that require users and/or groups to be added.

You must set this variable if the recipe inherits the class. For example, the following enables adding a user for the main package in a recipe:

```
     USERADD_PACKAGES = "${PN}"

```

### Note

If follows that if you are going to use the `USERADD_PACKAGES` variable, you need to set one or more of the [`USERADD_PARAM`][3389], [`GROUPADD_PARAM`][3390], or [`GROUPMEMS_PARAM`][3391]variables.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">USERADD_PARAM[¶][3392]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When inheriting the [`useradd`][3393] class, this variable specifies for a package what parameters should be passed to the `useradd` command if you wish to add a user to the system when the package is installed.

Here is an example from the `dbus` recipe:

```
     USERADD_PARAM_${PN} = "--system --home ${localstatedir}/lib/dbus \
                            --no-create-home --shell /bin/false \
                            --user-group messagebus"

```

For information on the standard Linux shell command `useradd`, see[http://linux.die.net/man/8/useradd][3394].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">USERADD_UID_TABLES[¶][3395]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies a password file to use for obtaining static user identification (`uid`) values when the OpenEmbedded build system adds a user to the system during package installation.

When applying static user identification (`uid`) values, the OpenEmbedded build system looks in[`BBPATH`][3396] for a `files/passwd` file and then applies those `uid` values. Set the variable as follows in your`local.conf` file:

```
     USERADD_UID_TABLES = "files/passwd"

```

### Note

Setting the [`USERADDEXTENSION`][3397] variable to "useradd-staticids" causes the build system to use static `uid` values.</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">USERADDEXTENSION[¶][3398]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When set to "useradd-staticids", causes the OpenEmbedded build system to base all user and group additions on a static `passwd` and `group` files found in [`BBPATH`][3399].

To use static user identification (`uid`) and group identification (`gid`) values, set the variable as follows in your `local.conf` file:

```
     USERADDEXTENSION = "useradd-staticids"

```

### Note

Setting this variable to use static `uid` and `gid` values causes the OpenEmbedded build system to employ the [`useradd-staticids`][3400] class.

If you use static `uid` and `gid` information, you must also specify the `files/passwd` and `files/group`files by setting the [`USERADD_UID_TABLES`][3401] and [`USERADD_GID_TABLES`][3402] variables. Additionally, you should also set the [`USERADD_ERROR_DYNAMIC`][3403] variable.

</dd>

</dl>

### V

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">VOLATILE_LOG_DIR[¶][3404]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the persistence of the target's `/var/log` directory, which is used to house postinstall target log files.

By default, `VOLATILE_LOG_DIR` is set to "yes", which means the file is not persistent. You can override this setting by setting the variable to "no" to make the log directory persistent.

</dd>

</dl>

### W

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">WARN_QA[¶][3405]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the quality assurance checks whose failures are reported as warnings by the OpenEmbedded build system. You set this variable in your distribution configuration file. For a list of the checks you can control with this variable, see the "[`insane.bbclass`][3406]" section.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">WKS_FILE_DEPENDS[¶][3407]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

When placed in the recipe that builds your image, this variable lists build-time dependencies. The `WKS_FILE_DEPENDS` variable is only applicable when Wic images are active (i.e. when [`IMAGE_FSTYPES`][3408]contains entries related to Wic). If your recipe does not create Wic images, the variable has no effect.

The `WKS_FILE_DEPENDS` variable is similar to the [`DEPENDS`][3409] variable. When you use the variable in your recipe that builds the Wic image, dependencies you list in the `WIC_FILE_DEPENDS` variable are added to the `DEPENDS` variable.

With the `WKS_FILE_DEPENDS` variable, you have the possibility to specify a list of additional dependencies (e.g. native tools, bootloaders, and so forth), that are required to build Wic images. Following is an example:

```
     WKS_FILE_DEPENDS = "some-native-tool"

```

In the previous example,  _`some-native-tool`_  would be replaced with an actual native tool on which the build would depend.

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">WKS_FILE[¶][3410]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the location of the Wic kickstart file that is used by the OpenEmbedded build system to create a partitioned image ( _`image`_ `.wic`). For information on how to create a partitioned image, see the "[Creating Partitioned Images][3411]" section. For details on the kickstart file format, see the "[OpenEmbedded Kickstart (`.wks`) Reference][3412].

</dd>

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">WORKDIR[¶][3413]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

The pathname of the work directory in which the OpenEmbedded build system builds a recipe. This directory is located within the [`TMPDIR`][3414] directory structure and is specific to the recipe being built and the system for which it is being built.

The `WORKDIR` directory is defined as follows:

```
     ${TMPDIR}/work/${MULTIMACH_TARGET_SYS}/${PN}/${EXTENDPE}${PV}-${PR}

```

The actual directory depends on several things:

*   [`TMPDIR`][696]: The top-level build output directory

*   [`MULTIMACH_TARGET_SYS`][697]: The target system identifier

*   [`PN`][698]: The recipe name

*   [`EXTENDPE`][699]: The epoch - (if [`PE`][700] is not specified, which is usually the case for most recipes, then `EXTENDPE` is blank)

*   [`PV`][701]: The recipe version

*   [`PR`][702]: The recipe revision

As an example, assume a Source Directory top-level folder name `poky`, a default Build Directory at`poky/build`, and a `qemux86-poky-linux` machine target system. Furthermore, suppose your recipe is named `foo_1.3.0-r0.bb`. In this case, the work directory the build system uses to build the package would be as follows:

```
     poky/build/tmp/work/qemux86-poky-linux/foo/1.3.0-r0

```
</dd>

</dl>

### X

<dl style="padding-top: 0em;">

<dt style="font-weight: normal; width: 20em; text-align: right; color: rgb(0, 68, 68);">XSERVER[¶][3415]</dt>

<dd style="margin-top: 0em; margin-left: 25.5em;">

Specifies the packages that should be installed to provide an X server and drivers for the current machine, assuming your image directly includes `packagegroup-core-x11-xserver` or, perhaps indirectly, includes "x11-base" in [`IMAGE_FEATURES`][3416].

The default value of `XSERVER`, if not specified in the machine configuration, is "xserver-xorg xf86-video-fbdev xf86-input-evdev".

</dd>

</dl>

### Chapter 15. Variable Context[¶][3417]

While you can use most variables in almost any context such as `.conf`, `.bbclass`, `.inc`, and `.bb` files, some variables are often associated with a particular locality or context. This chapter describes some common associations.

### 15.1. Configuration[¶][1542]

The following subsections provide lists of variables whose context is configuration: distribution, machine, and local.

### 15.1.1. Distribution (Distro)[¶][703]

This section lists variables whose configuration context is the distribution, or distro.

*   `[DISTRO][704]`

*   `[DISTRO_NAME][705]`

*   `[DISTRO_VERSION][706]`

*   `[MAINTAINER][707]`

*   `[PACKAGE_CLASSES][708]`

*   `[TARGET_OS][709]`

*   `[TARGET_FPU][710]`

*   `[TCMODE][711]`

*   `[TCLIBC][712]`

### 15.1.2. Machine[¶][713]

This section lists variables whose configuration context is the machine.

*   `[TARGET_ARCH][714]`

*   `[SERIAL_CONSOLES][715]`

*   `[PACKAGE_EXTRA_ARCHS][716]`

*   `[IMAGE_FSTYPES][717]`

*   `[MACHINE_FEATURES][718]`

*   `[MACHINE_EXTRA_RDEPENDS][719]`

*   `[MACHINE_EXTRA_RRECOMMENDS][720]`

*   `[MACHINE_ESSENTIAL_EXTRA_RDEPENDS][721]`

*   `[MACHINE_ESSENTIAL_EXTRA_RRECOMMENDS][722]`

### 15.1.3. Local[¶][723]

This section lists variables whose configuration context is the local configuration through the `local.conf` file.

*   `[DISTRO][724]`

*   `[MACHINE][725]`

*   `[DL_DIR][726]`

*   `[BBFILES][727]`

*   `[EXTRA_IMAGE_FEATURES][728]`

*   `[PACKAGE_CLASSES][729]`

*   `[BB_NUMBER_THREADS][730]`

*   `[BBINCLUDELOGS][731]`

*   `[ENABLE_BINARY_LOCALE_GENERATION][732]`

### 15.2. Recipes[¶][1543]

The following subsections provide lists of variables whose context is recipes: required, dependencies, path, and extra build information.

### 15.2.1. Required[¶][733]

This section lists variables that are required for recipes.

*   `[LICENSE][734]`

*   `[LIC_FILES_CHKSUM][735]`

*   `[SRC_URI][736]` - used in recipes that fetch local or remote files.

### 15.2.2. Dependencies[¶][737]

This section lists variables that define recipe dependencies.

*   `[DEPENDS][738]`
